Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, I have a question of you. It also relates to the question of the tabling of documents. On your election to the role of Speaker you made it clear that you would not be allowing the tabling of readily available public documents such as newspapers. An incident during question time today made me reflect on your ruling. If a minister were to quote from a relatively obscure rural newspaper from somewhere far away, particularly if he were quoting from a newspaper that was some months old, it could take the opposition hours, if not days, to secure a copy of that newspaper article and therefore read the text in full. On that basis, I believe the opposition has been put at a disadvantage and the government has been put at an advantage and I would ask you to seriously reflect on and reconsider your decision.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I appreciate the comments of the member for Hunter, but I still come back to the point that a newspaper is a publicly available document. Presentation of Documents

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, as this is the time for questions to you, I wonder if you could approach the Minister for Education, Science and Training to counsel him on the subject of that letter that he quoted from but refused to table. Clearly, it was not a document that was marked as confidential, which is a requirement. That is the first point. The second point as to why I would ask you to do that is that, on the basis of this document, the person concerned has been appointed to a public committee to do an inquiry. Evidently, the views that were expressed in that were important to the fact that she has been appointed. So it is no longer a private document. It was rendered public by the quoting from it in the first instance and, now that it has become the basis on which her appointment was made, it is doubly so. This is a document that should be presented to this parliament, it having been asked for. It is clearly not confidential.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: The question was posed to the minister. The minister has given an answer. If the minister chooses to reconsider, then I think that is at the minister's discretion, but his answer stands. Mr Latham- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I would ask you to reconsider the two rulings that you have made to the House. You have expelled the member for Batman for questioning whether or not a document exists. It is a document that we have not seen, a document that has not been tabled. A document that does exist, that is a public document not marked ‘confidential', you have said cannot be tabled. It is impossible for the opposition to live under that double standard. One of our members has had to leave the chamber, and his constituents are not represented for an hour, on the basis document for which there is no evidence whether or not it exists. Yet a document that is known to exist, a public document that we require tabled, you just said that you will take the minister's word for it without making any further investigations, as suggested by the member for Brand. You said you would be firm but fair. Where is the fairness in that?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I have ruled on that matter. Parliament House: Security

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I have a question to you, Mr Speaker. Is it the case that the federal parliament is alone among the nation's parliaments, and indeed the parliaments of comparable established democracies, in requiring that MPs pass through a full-body scanner and, further, that they may be required to be subjected to a hand scan? If this is so, why are Australian MPs singled out in this way? Further, what, if any, action can and will be taken against MPs refusing to subject themselves to this process?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the member for Fremantle. I will take that question on notice and get back to the House. NA NA Report

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: COMMISSIONER
text: I present the Parliamentary Service Commissioner's report for 2003-04. The report was received by my predecessor after the dissolution of the House on 31 August 2004. Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper. AUDITOR-GENERAL'S REPORTS Report No. 15 of 2004-05

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: COMMISSIONER
text: I present the Auditorof a General's audit report No. 15 of 2004-05 entitled Financial management of Special Appropriations. Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper. NA

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: DOCUMENTS
text: Documents are presented as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the documents will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings. NA Foreign Affairs: Asia-Pacific Region

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Griffith proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The Howard Government's refusal to abandon the doctrine of regional military pre-emption the Government's failure to secure Australia's long-term national interests in our region. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If there is one word that characterises the political culture of the Howard government since the election, it is the word ‘arrogance'. What we have seen today in question time is a government dripping with arrogance. Each minister at this dispatch box has dripped with arrogance: arrogance in victory. They are too arrogant to answer questions which are being put legitimately in this parliament to which they are responsible. We have seen arrogance over their impending control of the Senate; arrogance from ‘Captain Smirk' himself, the Treasurer of the Commonwealth; arrogance over the state of the economy, despite the collapse in exports; and arrogance on education, despite the collapse in public investment in human capital. But arrogance, too, in foreign policy-arrogance here in our own region and, regrettably, arrogance at a time when we face an unprecedented opportunity to broaden the terms of Australia's regional engagement in Asia. In fact, arrogance has become the hallmark of this, the fourth Howard government. This is a matter of public importance, and it is worth asking ourselves the question: why is the region important to Australia? Basically, if you look at the economic datait does not matter what set of statistics you look at-you will see that our future as an economy will be entirely shaped by the economies of this region over the next half century. China, it is projected by Goldman Sachs, will have an economy larger than that of Germany by 2010, than that of Japan by and 2015 and than that of the United States by 2039. India will follow, a generation later. Our regional economies will shape fundamentally the state of our national economy. Beyond this, we see them also now radically affecting growth patterns, trade patterns and investment patterns across the entire global economy of which we are part. That is one reason why this is legitimately a matter of public importance. The second reason is security. If you look at our region today, you will see that it has within it many unresolved security crises and tensions which affect our national well-being, whether they are the Korean peninsula, the Taiwan Straits or the unresolved challenge of Islamist terrorist organisations here in South East Asia. The Curtin doctrine of half a century ago remains as valid now for Australia as it was then-that is, our security is, first and foremost, shaped by the security developments of our own region, our own neighbourhood, our own backyard. As we embrace this new century, for these core reasons of the economy and our security, what must we as a country of 20 million people now do? We face some pretty big decisions. There are basically two groups of decisions we can take. The first is to sit back and allow it all to happen-to allow these developments to wash over us for good or for ill, to periodically try and insulate ourselves from the region and to try and pick up at the edges some advantages which may flow in our direction. That is a passive strategy-the strategy of this government. There is an alternative approach-an active approach and an activist strategy in the tradition of previous Labor governments, which is this: to actively seek to shape the emerging security and economic architecture of East Asia. That is the path which this country should embrace, because the truth now is that in the corridors of power across our region debates are now occurring about the future shape of East Asia: about its future institutional shape and the future architecture of an East Asian community-an East Asian economic community. At present we are excluded from those debates. As a consequence of that, when the rules are set and the instituAustralia-that tions have already been formed we shall come too late to the table. That is this Minister for Foreign Affairs'-this missing minister's-recipe for Australia's foreign policy future. We are proud of our record on these questions. We have much to be proud of as an activist Labor Party with an activist foreign policy. APEC is an Australian Labor government's creation. The ASEAN Regional Forum is an Australian Labor government's creation. Why were these institutions created during the Hawke and Keating governments? The answer is very simple: so that we could ourselves, from an Australian national interest point of view, shape the architecture of our region for the next century. But these things have been allowed to wilt on the vine. It is no coincidence whatsoever that during the custodianship of this foreign minister and his equally missing Prime Minister these institutions have lost momentum. That Australian momentum was key to their future because we were in the driving seat for so long. But from the 1990s on-from 1997, with the Asian financial crisis, when APEC was incapable of a systemic response to the crises washing over the economies of East Asia-a parallel institution began to emerge called ASEAN plus 3, which is the now 10 governments of the Association of South-East Asian Nations linking with the three principal economies of North-East Asia: China, Japan and the Republic of Korea. They began to meet in the corridors of the APEC meeting. They began to meet at a time when APEC failed to deliver the economic outcome which was necessary to respond effectively to the Asian financial crisis. Between them these 13 economies represent a massive slice of global GDP and in the future an even greater slice. But what is the key difference from APEC? There is no America and no is the key difference. This institution, ASEAN plus 3, is now evolving in a way whereby the future architecture of our region is being shaped by their internal deliberations on the economy and on broader foreign policy as well. You see, what is happening is that in these corridors of power discussions are occurring, modelled on what occurred in Europe half a century ago, about how to create an East Asian economic community and how to create an East Asian community-which has a foreign policy function as well-and about having regular East Asian summits. The problem for us is that we are nowhere near the table. If you roll the clock on a decade or two, what you can see is an East Asian community-headquartered maybe in Shanghai, maybe in Singapore-and Australia not being at the table, or at least not being at the table early enough. These are the critical issues which are now before us when we come to look at the agenda in Vientiane. The challenge for Australia is how do we, as a country, now get into shape this agenda? You see, in the past there have been reasons which have got in the road, and not all of them are the fault of this government. Dr Mahathir Mohamad was Prime Minister of Malaysia. He did not like the Keating government and he certainly did not like the Howard government. But we have seen a number of things since then whereby the Howard government has added to the lead in Australia's saddlebags. In 1999 we had the Howard government talking about Australia as the US deputy sheriff in South-East Asia-a fit of foreign policy triumphalism following the Timor operation. In 2001 we had a meltdown in the Australia-Indonesia relationship after Prime Minister Howard publicly blamed President Megawati Sukarnoputri for the problem of asylum seekers coming to Australia. If you roll the clock on to 2002 you have the granddaddy of them all: the Howard doctrine of military preemption. What do we mean by that, by the way? It basically says to your neighbours, ‘We reserve the right to one day launch a military strike on your territory.' When I read the textbooks that equals war, but they call it military pre-emption. That is currently the formal declaratory policy of the government of the Commonwealth of Australia, and this mob who call themselves the government sit there and wonder why the region has a few problems with this. You can begin to understand if you put the tables in reverse and Australia at the receiving end of a doctrine announced in Jakarta one day which said, ‘We reserve for ourselves a right of military pre-emption against Australia. We may strike any time at the Kimberleys should we think that insufficient action was being taken against a group in the Kimberleys by the Australian government'-otherwise known as the Downer doctrine. I think the Australian people would have a few problems with that. That is what we have got, courtesy of this foreign minister. This year, however, despite the government's historical form, there have been significant changes which present new opportunities for us. Dr Mahathir has retired. Abdullah Badawi is now Prime Minister of Malaysia and is welcoming of Australia. We have a new President in Indonesia who is similarly welcoming towards Australia despite the past. And Australia, for the first time in 30 years, has an invitation to participate in a summit with the heads of government of the 10 ASEAN nations. We should be grasping these opportunities with both our hands, to use them to ensure that we have a place in the future and to shape our region's future architecture. But, instead, we have a government which effectively says to the region, ‘You can go and jump in the lake.' That is effectively what they are saying-‘You can go and jump in the lake.' Look at what the region has said to us. The ASEAN foreign ministers said the other day, on 27 November, that they would welcome Australian participation in the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation. The Chair of ASEAN, the Prime Minister of Laos, said overnight that Australia could accede to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation. The Malaysian foreign minister said Australia's accession would send a ‘gesture of goodwill and understanding' to the region. The Thai chief foreign policy spokesman said it was put high time Australia acceded, as other regional governments have done. The spokesman for the Philippines' President said she would be raising this with Mr Howard directly. And on the key question of the link between this Treaty of Amity and Cooperation and a future East Asian community, we go to the Indonesian government, whose foreign policy spokesman the other day said: We are thinking about countries like India, Australia and New Zealand and whether they should be participating in an East Asian summit. This is not a proposal ... we are thinking out loud. Asked if signing a peace pact would help inclusion in the East Asian dialogue, he said: It is not a prerequisite but it would seem logical corollary and consistent. You cannot have a more positive set of invitations from the region to grasp this opportunity with both hands, but again the Howard government's response has been to tell the region: ‘You can go and drop dead, you can go and get lost, you can go and jump in the lake.' Two stated reasons were given to us. The first, completely fatuous, by ‘HMAS Foreign Minister' over there, is this: he says, ‘We can't do that because we're an ally of the United States.' For goodness sake, have you studied recently the foreign policy of Japan? I thought they were an ally of the United States. Have you studied recently the foreign policy history of the Republic of Korea? I thought they were also an ally of the United States. Have you noted recently, namely in 2004, that both these countries have signed the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation with the ASEAN countries? Of course they have. That argument is fatuous and you know it. The second reason, I reckon, is the bobbydazzler of them all. It says that you cannot sign the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation because it would impede this minister launching on his human rights campaign in the region, particularly against Burma. Can everyone recall Mr Downer's loud public campaign against the Burmese regime? Can you remember his policy of human rights constructive engagement with the Burmese military junta? Can you remember also what a particularly successful policy that has been? Have you noticed this morning's news report that Aung San Suu Kyi has been given another 12 months in home detention? I do not think it has succeeded, Minister. But the principle you argue is this: if you sign this thing you cannot talk about human rights in the region. There is a problem. Alex has a problem. Alex's problem is called: Dr Mahathir Mohamad. Dr Mahathir Mohamadto be a whom I thought was the Prime Minister of Malaysia, a member of ASEAN and, therefore, a signatory to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation-only last year said: Wein Malaysiaare very disappointed over these thingsin Burmaand, of course, we have done our very best to try to get them to change their minds. That is a statement from the Malaysian Prime Minister, hopping right into the Burmese regime. So much for the TAC, the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation, preventing the Malaysian Prime Minister from hopping into the Burmese, and they were all members of ASEAN-they are not even external adherents to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation. That argument goes down in a screaming heap. Why has the minister advanced both these bogus arguments, apart from his jolly old Adelaide sense of humour? It is along these lines, Minister: you know, as I know, that the doctrine of military preemption stands there like a huge boulder in the middle of the road. And as a foreign policy professional himself in the past, he knows that that policy, frankly, is completely negative as far as Australia's long-term national security interests are concerned. The Howard doctrine of military pre-emption makes no sense whatsoever. We have a Prime Minister trying to wriggle out from under it, saying, ‘Oh, gee, we'll never use it anyway.' It begs the question: if you would never use it, why have it? If you do not believe that this doctrine is valid for Australia's circumstances then why do you maintain it? The bottom line is this: that is the real reason. My appeal to the parliament, and through the parliament to the executive and to this minister, is this: given that Australia's long term national economic and security interests are at stake here, is it too much to ask, Minister, for you to have the courage of your convictions to formally advise your Prime Minister that he has got it wrong, that he needs to swallow his pride, say that this thing is absolutely incompatible with Australia's national security and foreign policy interests and indicate a positive response to the possibility of Australia embracing the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation. That is the challenge which lies in your in-tray, Minister for Foreign Affairs. If you are in any way up to the challenges of the office which you hold, you would discharge it with courage, not with the lack of courage we have seen today. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This MPI, on the day when the Prime Minister is in Vientiane at the historic summit with 10 ASEAN heads of government, is a spiteful MPI. It is driven by spite, because if you supported Australia's participation in the region you would use today as a day to celebrate what the government has achieved and what the Prime Minister is doing; you would not, as an act of spite, move a motion in the parliament to attack the Prime Minister on this very day. I regard this as a typical example of what has happened to the Australian Labor Party. Its day-by-day tactic is based on newspapers but no strategy. No thought goes into what the mediumand long-term approach of the Australian Labor Party should be. We have childish hyperbole from the opposition spokesman on foreign affairs about how Australia is trashing its relations with Asia on the very same day that the Prime Minister is in Asia at a historic summit. How mature would the political point be that, for all the breathlessjust ness of the Keating government about engaging with our own neighbours-as though somehow there was something unnatural about engaging with your own neighboursthey never went to a summit of this kind, and nor did the Hawke government? There are historic reasons for why these things happen and why they do not happen, but as a government we have been committed to building our engagement with Asia, but we do it from a position of strength and national pridenot a position of begging, not a position of weakness-and we have achieved great things. Today is a day when you would expect more than one side of the parliament to be celebrating the achievement of Australia beginning to negotiate a free trade area between Australia, New Zealand and the 10 ASEAN countries. Other than the FTA that we have negotiated with the United States of America, this has the potential to be one of the greatest steps forward in Australian trade and foreign policy. And the Labor Party uses a day like this to move a childish, hyperbolic motion like this, just out of spite. If I may say so, it explains why they lost the last election: no strategy, no intellectual thought given, just tactics day by day. Tom Allard, from the Sydney Morning Herald, writes a beat-up story about the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation-and who is first to the microphone? None other than the member for Griffith, driven not only by political expediency but by his passionate desire to replace the member for Werriwa as the Leader of the Opposition. The last time he had a go at that, he had one vote: he had the vote of the member for Griffith. He had no other votes, so he had to withdraw. He is having another go at it-that is what he is dedicated to doing-and spiteful MPIs of this kind being moved by the opposition on a day of great achievement for Australian foreign policy about says it all. It just about says it all about the opposition. Today is Tuesday. Next Monday, the foreign minister of Indonesia and I will be chairing and co-hosting, in Yogyakarta, a historic interfaith dialogue, bringing together religious leaders from the different countries in the region to promote religious tolerance and to talk about the bonds that different religions represented through this region have and the values that these religions share. This is an initiative being pursued by the Australian government in cooperation with the Indonesian government, and yet we have this childish assertion-and it can be called nothing more than childish-that the government does not wish to engage with Asia. The Australian foreign minister and the Thai foreign minister a few months ago in Bangkok co-hosted the second regional ministerial HIV-AIDS summit. HIV-AIDS is a big issue in the region; it is something that I think we, as a sophisticated and successful country, should make a contribution to addressing in the region. We co-hosted the second of those summits. The first of those summits was held in Melbourne in October 2001. It was chaired by me, and that was the first time ministers from the Asia-Pacific region had got together to address the issue of HIV-AIDS. The member for Griffith talks about arrogance. He moves an MPI but then arrogantly listens to none of the debate except his own hyperbolic remarks, his spiteful remarks. He has nothing else to offer to this parliament but spite and hyperbole. This was a very historic contribution by Australia to addressing the issue of HIV-AIDS in the region. When it came to counter-terrorism, it was Australia, with Indonesia, which co-hosted in February this year the first Asia-Pacific ministerial meeting on counter-terrorism, which was another historic contribution by Australia to the affairs of the region. Out of that been established the Jakarta Centre for Law Enforcement Cooperation. It is an Australian-Indonesian initiative, and it is helping to develop the capabilities the region needs to counter terrorism. I think we have signed nine bilateral memoranda of understanding on counter-terrorism with our regional neighbours, and we signed a counterterrorism declaration with ASEAN as a whole. It is another illustration of the work the government is doing in the region this time to address the issue of terrorism and to help to develop the capacity of the region to deal with the issue of terrorism. On the economic front, I hope Australians generally, and the parliament in particular, will understand that today is a very historic day in terms of our long-term prospects for economic integration with the region, which I myself am very committed to. The Labor Party of course wants to distract people's attention from this to the parliament, because it does not want them to see the government succeed. The government has been democratically elected by the people of Australia, regrettable as that may be to the Australian Labor Party, and the government is the government of Australia, whatever political party it may comprise. I would have hoped all Australians today would wish the Prime Minister well at this historic summit. I think all Australians, except for the 60-I think there are only 60-members of the Australian Labor Party in this chamber do wish the Prime Minister well. It does not matter whether they are Labor voters in the electorates of Greenway, La Trobe or Bowman or whichever electorate they may be in or whether they are Labor voters in the electorate of Mayo-and 16 per cent of people in my electorate voted Labor at the last election; there were some. Ms Gillard-Name them!

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I think I could, actually; has I think I pretty much know who they are! Mr Ripoll interjecting

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is the modern Labor Party; it is the Labor Party of 2004. In Ben Chifley's day they did much better down there in what is now Mayo. I am sure all those Labor voters wish the Prime Minister well on this historic day-except the 60 members of the Latham Labor Party in here, who wish the Prime Minister a terrible day and hope everything goes wrong. The member for Griffith has been doing all he can to whip up opposition to the Prime Minister.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is entirely true. You have no strategy; in the Labor Party you just have tactics. The election may be over, but there will be another one. It will be in three years time. For three years we are going to keep belting you about not having any strategy, not having any tactics, not having any policies. Mr Ripoll interjecting

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I would like to know who you are. I believe you are a member of the House of Representatives. You have a badge on your lapel. You have not made much of an impact here, I can assure you.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Order! The minister will refer his remarks through the chair.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: But seriously, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Labor Party wishes ill will on the Prime Minister today, and they would not have moved this spiteful MPI if they did not. It is a classic example of what is wrong with Latham Labor. The member for Griffith wants it to be Rudd Labor. Rudd Labor? I think not, actually. I do not think that is ing to happen. But nevertheless it is the fact that there is an opportunity here to get into the media. Doorstops are held, and sincerely held. The phrases have all been thought out beforehand. Out they come: ‘the horrific Howard government', ‘Howard's a fascist'-all this sort of stuff-‘Howard hates Asia'. It all comes pouring out: the invective, the abuse, the denigration and-you come back to the word-the spite. It is all there. And then off he goes, prances off into his office, no doubt makes himself a cup of tea or coffee or whatever he does in his office in the morning and rings up a few of his mates just to make sure they are onside, sharpening their knives and putting their knives into Biff-that is the game most of the day. Another opportunity arises: somebody says, ‘What are we going to move an MPI on today?' That is one of the things you can do in opposition: you can spend the morning talking about what the MPI is going to be. I remember. You have to have it in by 12 o'clock, so you all ring each other up: ‘Oh, please, can I have it?' And Mr Spiteful here rings up and says, ‘Can I put in an MPI saying Howard is a dud on the day he's having a summit with the ASEAN leaders? Please, Biff, can I put in an MPI saying Howard's a dud?' And what does Biff say? ‘Yes, of course, mate. I don't know what's going on. I've never even heard of the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation, mate. In Green Valley we haven't been hearing of that.' And that is what it is all about; that is what has happened here today. The opposition have never asked a question about the free trade agreement between Australia, ASEAN and New Zealand. They used to attack the FTA with the United States, and they asked a lot of questions about that. The Leader of the Opposition came out and initially said he was opposed to goit. ‘If I had to vote on that today, I'd vote all about against it,' is what he said Ms Gillard interjecting

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: That is right. That was why he said he would vote against it. But we have an FTA with Thailand. Do the opposition even know what the FTA with Thailand is about? Some of the members of the opposition are so invisible they would not even know there was an FTA with Thailand, or the FTA with Singapore, or the prospect of an FTA with Malaysia, or the prospect of an FTA with China. Are these of any interest to the opposition? There are no questions about them, just about the United States, because the old bourgeois left of the Labor Party are pretty anti-American. We have heard about the branch meetings-all the sneering and jeering at Bush, the Bushies and all this sort of thing. We know what goes on in the Labor Party, and it all spills over into here. They were against a free trade agreement with the United States, but eventually realised that was too politically difficult to susthing tain, and never even raised a question about free trade agreements with any Asian country at all-not a question. They are not serious. This is not a political party which should be taken seriously any longer at the federal level. They have had their opportunity to work through decent policies, to think up a strategy. And they lost the election-that is fair enough. It is tough when you lose an election, but you have to come back and rebuild. Mr Rudd-You are so funny!

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Most of us do not laugh with joy when we lose elections, even if the member for Griffith does. Usually when we lost elections we felt a bit depressed, but not the member for Griffith, because he sees it as his chance-his chance to get the leadership of the Australian Labor Party. By the way, I can predict you won't. But the fact is the Labor Party have started the new parliament making exactly the same mistakes they made in the last one and the one before that. The last two elections in a row they have gone backwards and further backwards. And in this parliament they are going to use the same tactics. This MPI is a tactical and a strategic mistake. Labor should support the government in its engagement with Asia, not be spiteful.

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: There has been a visible change in the government. People today have really noticed it. We saw today-as the foreign affairs minister scurries out of the chamber-that there has been a huge visible change in the government's attitude, in the way it is presenting ideas, in the way it is putting forward its fourth-term agenda. There is no doubt that, with that visible change, it believes, firstly, that it is invincible-that all its policies have been somehow vindicated, that it is right in everyit does; and, secondly, that it can do no wrong-no matter what it says, no matter what it does, no matter what its policies are, there is just no way it can do any wrong. But what is more disturbing is that it thinks it has some sort of absolute mandate to take every single idea it has and project it forward-that everything it has as an idea and policy suddenly has an absolute mandate from the community. The government is absolutely wrong on that count. Before I go on with that I want to make mention of the commitment of the foreign affairs minister to this topic. He says we should take it seriously, but have a look at the time that this minister actually spent in the 15 minutes that he had on the clock to actually deal with the issue, to actually deal with the treaty. He probably spent about 12 minutes out of 15 talking about the Labor Party, talking about our electoral aspirations, talking about us; he spent very little time talking about the actual treaty itself. I think that shows the dedication; it shows the time the minister has actually spent either (a) understanding the issue or (b) taking the issue seriously. Well, on this side of the House, we actually think this treaty is a very serious issue. What this government has done through its election win is become very arrogant. We heard that from the member for Griffith, who dealt very eloquently with this arrogance. We saw today in question time just how arrogant this government can be. The foreign affairs minister also spoke about the historic summit at which the Prime Minister is present today. I agree: this is a historic summit, a very important summit. He said that we do not wish the Prime Minister well. I think he is wrong. Members on this side actually do wish the Prime Minister well, because he is representing all of us-he is representing all of Australia. This is something the foreign affairs minister does not understand. The arrogance has gotten to his brain and he does not understand that we do wish the Prime Minister well, because he represents all of us-he represents the people of Australia. We wish Australia well. We actually wish that we get something out of this summit. It has been a long, 30-year road to get to this summit, so we take it very seriously. The message I would give to the foreign affairs minister and, through him, the Prime Minister is: do not miss this opportunity. Do not miss this historic moment and this great opportunity that we have now been given. Do something significant with it rather than squander it by coming into this place, just talking about us and refusing to either listen to the Australian people or meet the needs of Australia. The minister came in here and spent the majority of his time talking about us and very little time actually dealing with the sues before him. But none of this is new. The people who have followed the speeches of the foreign affairs minister would understand a little bit of history about how we have actually got to today. They would understand the attitude of this government, the arrogance that I am talking about and their attitude of being the deputy sheriff of our region-a ridiculous proposition-or lap-dog of the United States. This is a silly policy that government has progressively tried to distance itself from but has not completely walked away from. We know that it is still there, locked away in their mind. It is still part of their arrogant thinking towards foreign affairs. The most ridiculous of all-it is more than ridiculous; it is actually frightening-is the one about military pre-emption. Somehow, in our neighbourhood and region, we are different to every other country. That is the message this Prime Minister and foreign affairs minister send out on a regular basis. Somehow we are not like they are. Somehow we are different. Somehow we can afford to have a different policy to the rest of our region. Somehow we can say to our neighbours, ‘We reserve the right to unilaterally come into your country and have a preemptive strike on your national territory because we believe that you may not be doing enough.' I see a couple of government members here, including one at the table. There are only two members of the government here. That is how important they think the debate on this treaty is. They have this attitude that just somehow we have this right. If the tables were reversed-and this is something the government should really think about-and any one of our regional neighbours were to copy identically the government's policy, what would be their reaction? What would be the foreign affairs minister's reaction if isMalaysia or the Philippines or Laos or any other nation in our region were to put into place the same policies? I think we would be a little bit concerned and we would have a right to be, just as they are concerned about this government's attitude towards them. We talk about missed opportunities, wishing the Prime Minister well and the great opportunities for Australia. I say: do not miss those opportunities; take them today. Go to this the ASEAN summit today, after a long, 30-year road towards us being involved, and take the opportunities. Seize the day and actually do something with this. We do wish the Prime Minister well on behalf of all Australians. This Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in South-East Asia is not a new one. It actually dates back to 24 February 1976. I want to put two of its articles on record. Article 1 says: The purpose of this Treaty is to promote perpetual peace, everlasting amity and cooperation among their peoples which would contribute to their strength, solidarity and closer relationship, I do not see anything too wrong with that. I actually think that is a good thing. That is something that we on this side of the House support. I cannot understand why the government would not support such a proposition. Article 2 of the treaty states that the signatories: ... shall be guided by the following fundamental principles: a. Mutual respect for the independence, sovereignty, equality, territorial integrity and national identity of all nations; I do not see too much wrong in that. I think this is a good thing. This is something that the government should support. It also states that other fundamental principles are the right of every state to lead its national existence free from external interference, subversion or coercion and no interference in the international affairs of one another's states. Settlement of differences or disputes by peaceful means, the renunciation of the threat of use of force and effective cooperation among themselves should be the guiding principles. These principles, to all fair minded Australians, would be more than reasonable. We would say, ‘Please, can we line up to sign this treaty? This is a fair and good thing.' But somehow this government thinks it is not. Somehow this government is telling the people of Australia, our regional neighbours and the global community that it does not agree with mutual respect for independence, sovereignty, equality, territorial integrity or national identity of all nations. How can that be? How can this government be so arrogant domestically and globally that it would refuse to sign this treaty? I am bewildered by its attitude. We have had the necessity today of coming into this chamber to put this very important public matter before the chamber and raise this issue. This should have been a non-issue. This should have been a great opportunity seized upon by this government to actually give Australia a renewed international image of cooperation with our regional neighbours and partners which we could have been proud of into the future rather than the sort of foreign affairs direction that we have been getting from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Prime Minister or, for that matter, many people on the government benches. I think that if most reasonably minded government backbenchers took the time to read the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation they would be asking questions within their own caucus as to whyMr Cameron Thompson-Have you read it?

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I would ask the member for Blair whether he has read it. Would you like me to table it for you? I do not think that the member for Blair realises that the treaty actually exists. What he should realise-and this is very important-is that his government is actually standing in the way of a great opportunity for Australia. Mr Cameron Thompson-Not true!

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: He says he could not agree more. I agree with him. This is a great opportunity for Australia. We should seize the day and do something positive. Let my voice and that of the member for Griffith, the shadow foreign affairs minister, not be the only voices on why we should be a part of this treaty. The government gives only two excuses. I would just put them down as excuses as I cannot see that they are much more than that. One is that somehow this would restrict the government's ability to speak up on human rights abuses. I will not go into great detail in reference to Burma, in particular, because I do not have enough time left on the clock. The reality is that they just excuses and they are not satisfactory. In conclusion, I say that we will miss a great opportunity. It is obvious from what is happening today with the Prime Minister at the summit is that he is putting his own personal perspectives and interests above the national interest. That concerns me. Australia does deserve better. We all deserve better. This should be a government for all of the people, not just some of the people.

Speaker: Mr CAMERON THOMPSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am glad to hear that the member for Oxley wishes the Prime Minister well in his endeavours in Vientiane. I cannot help but notice the irony of having a member for Oxley wishing the Prime Minister well in going to Vientiane to seek to advance Australia's position and develop issues such as free trade in the world marketplace. Historically, the idea of those words coming from a member for Oxley might be a surprise for some, but I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there are many people in Australia-the vast majority of Australians-who are wishing the Prime Minister well in these endeavours because the opportunities for Australia that flow from this are fantastic, and we really need to be part of it. I do, however, agree with the Minister for Foreign Affairs when he cites the spite that is coming from the opposition foreign affairs spokesman on this issue. Why is there spite coming from him? The fact is that Labor, in opposition and in the time they were in government, built this massive molehill around their commitment to Asia, their pre-eminence in their devotion to Asia and their willingness to place a relationship with Asia above everything else, and that included many of the other important relationships that Australia holds throughout the world. The fact is that today really is the high point of our relationship with Asia. Through the are ASEAN leaders' forum we have tremendous opportunity to develop free trade for the benefit of Australia, and it is happening now; it is not happening courtesy of a Labor Party government, courtesy of a Labor Party initiative. That is where the spite springs from. What was the lowest point in our relationship with that region? It was probably the celebrated time when the former Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating made some illadvised comments about the Malaysian leader Mahathir Mohamad. He made the statement at the time that the Malaysian leader was a recalcitrant, which has echoed down the years to today. It has echoed again and again and it still is with us today. In fact, it has taken this Prime Minister and this government to develop the relationship to the point it is at today from the low point we experienced at that time. Now we are approaching the prospect of the first visit by Abdullah Badawi, the Malaysian Prime Minister. That is the first opportunity for a visit from a Malaysian Prime Minister to our shores in 20 years. The milestone that this represents has been trumpeted in the media in Australia, quite correctly. Even as far back as June 2004 the Age wrote that the ‘moves point to a major change in bilateral relations after years of political upheaval'. So it really is very much a high point in our relationship with Asia. One thing that should be looked at very closely is the statement by the opposition foreign affairs spokesman that Australia's future will be entirely shaped by the economies of this region. That is the core of the Labor Party view on this issue. I think we should look, for a moment, at the United States economy and what sort of impact that has on the world and on Australia's place in the world and our opportunities for trade. In 1980 the US accounted for 25 per cent of the world economy. In 2001 the US economy accounted for 34 per cent, or more than a third, of world GDP. That is still the world's greatest, biggest economy. US military expenditure is nearly $400 billion-six times that of the next largest, Russia, at $60 billion, and 10 times that of China at $42 billion. So to say that Australia's future will be entirely shaped by the economies of this region, as the opposition likes to put it, is cut out the US and say: ‘What is that? It is 34 per cent of the world GDP but, hey, our economy is going to be shaped by the region, and that's it.' This is a position that flows, suppose, from the anti-US position that has been articulated again and again, particularly by the Leader of the Opposition. It is mouthed also by his followers, people such as the member for Griffith. Of course, exports in this country are very important to us. Our opportunities in trade are very important, particularly in rural areas where it is estimated that one in four jobs comes from exports. The current problem with the current account deficit and the slide in the US dollar and the climb of the Australian dollar to US79c is a real challenge for us. How do we address that? We have to address that through better trade dealsthrough things such as the free trade agreement with the US, the trade deal that has been negotiated with Thailand and the trade deals with other countries, such as Singapore. We must set out to try and establish relationships that can overcome problems such as an Australian dollar at US79c. That is something that is a challenge. In my area, for example, the pork industry has to try to compete against overseas countries, many of whom are heavily subsidised. That high Australian dollar is something that is very hard for us to combat, and we have to try and establish for ourselves trade relationships that overcome it. Since the coalition came to government, our exports have increased in value from around $100 billion to around $143 billion-a 40 per cent increase over 8½ years at a time when world merchandise export growth has fallen. That is quite significant. These are the achievements of the coalition government. How are we doing it? By seeking to develop trade in this way. We do it effectively through measures to such as those being discussed in Vientiane. I would just like to quote, from the Melbourne Age editorial today, some of the opportunities that come from the possibility of I us establishing a free trade agreement involving ASEAN, Australia and New Zealand. It said: Annual two-way trade with Australia already stands at $33 billion and the summit's main goal has been to endorse a timetable to conclude a free trade agreement covering a market of more than 600 million people by as early as 2007that is a huge opportunity for Australia with the eventual prospect of an expanded free trade area involving partners such as China and India. This would cover a third of the world's population. If ASEAN begins these negotiations, Australia can consider this week a success. I say that it will be much more than a success; I say that it will be a huge triumph, a huge opportunity-something that I think sticks right in the craw of the member for Griffith, and he should not be taking that attitude. He should be applauding the steps that the government is taking, not seeking to sink the steps that the government is taking, seeking to belittle them. I would also like to touch on the rhetoric that the opposition are using to deal with this issue, this beat-up they are running in relation to what they call the doctrine of military pre-emption. In order to have something that is a doctrine of military pre-emption, you would have to be assuming that an attack on Australia was imminent, that there was no other way of addressing it and that the other country would not act, and therefore you would take direct action. Those are the sorts of things that have been taken into account in relation to Australia, with the position that the Prime Minister has articulated. He has said that, if there was likely to be an imminent attack, if there was no other way of addressing it and if the other country would not act to stop it, the government would act to defend Australians. That is a logical position. But to categorise it as a doctrine of military pre-emption is to infer that an tralia may not be imminent and yet you would still act, that you might attack when there was some other way of addressing it or that you might attack when the other country was prepared to act. Quite clearly, those important conditions, those circumstances that the Prime Minister has brought clearly front and centre, are being glossed over by members opposite and are being neglected and taken out of the debate. And those are very important issues, because it is a simple matter of logic that if Australian interests are threatened, at the end of it all, it is the obligation of every single member of this House and the Prime Minister to ensure that Australians are protected. That is our job, and that is the basic statement that has been made by the Prime Minister, something that is continually glossed over and misrepresented by the members opposite. Today they were characterising the policy, saying that the Prime Minister was saying, ‘Get lost, jump in the lake and drop dead.' That is the kind of beat-up that we are getting from members opposite, instead of proper consideration of the issues. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I present the report of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members' business on Monday, 6 December 2004. The report will be printed in today's Hansard and the items accorded priority for debate will be published in the Notice Paper for the next sitting. The report read as followsReport relating to the consideration of delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 6 December 2004 Pursuant to standing order 222, the Selection Committee has determined the order of precedence and times to be allotted for consideration of delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 6 December 2004. The order of precedence and the allotments of time determined by the Committee are as follows: NA Presentation and statements 1 PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO UKRAINE AND BULGARIA: Report of the Parliamentary Delegation to Ukraine and Bulgaria, 28 June to 9 July 2004. The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made - all statements to conclude by 12.40 p.m. Speech time limits Each Member -5 minutes. [Proposed Members speaking = 2 x 5 mins] 2 PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO NA FRANCE: Report of the Parliamentary Delegation to the European Institutions and France, April – May 2004. The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made - all statements to conclude by 12.45 p.m. Speech time limits Each Member -5 minutes. [Proposed Members speaking = 1 x 5 mins] PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS Order of precedence Notices 1 Ms George to move: That this House: (1) acknowledges the alarming growth in the ranks of ‘working poor' Australians; (2) notes that recent ABS data shows a disturbingly high level of financial pressure among the ‘working poor'; (3) notes that the majority of ‘working poor' Australians are totally reliant on minimum Award wages; (4) acknowledges the majority of Award workers are women in part-time and casual jobs serving the needs of others in the tail, health, childcare and community sectors; and (5) supports the system of annual wage increases to minimum Award rates as determined by the AIRC. (Notice given 16 November 2004.) Time allotted -30 minutes. Speech time limits Mover of motion -5 minutes. First Government Member speaking -5 minutes. Other Members -5 minutes each. [Proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins] The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day. 2 Mr A. D. H. Smith to move: That this House: (1) notes the terrible, and mostly unavoidable, consequences of death and injury occurring on Australia's roads each year; (2) notes the importance of Australia's car and truck drivers and motor cycle riders remembering to drive and ride safely at all times, being mindful of their passengers' safety and the safety of other road users; (3) notes the Australian Government's plans, as announced in May 2003, for a compulsory national program of driver education for all new provisional licence holders that aims to reduce the number of young people killed and maimed on our roads; (4) notes the critical need for all levels of government and the broader automotive and related industries to work cooperatively with the objective of promoting safer driving and to partially fund driver education for new, mostly young, drivers; and (5) recognises the successes and ongoing work of community-based organisations, including schools, in their efforts to teach and promote safer driving and other key road safety messages. (Notice given 17 November 2004.) Time allotted - remaining private Members' business time prior to 1.45 p.m. hospitality, reSpeech time limits Mover of motion -5 minutes. First Opposition Member speaking -5 minutes. Other Members -5 minutes each. [Proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins] The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day. 3 Mrs Irwin to move: That this House: (1) notes that 1,800 stateless Vietnamese people have been stranded in the Philippines since 1989 without residency status and are therefore ineligible to work or hold any rights of citizenship; (2) commends the Australian Government for granting humanitarian visas in the past four years to 68 stateless Vietnamese families comprising 260 people who have parents, children or siblings in Australia; (3) notes that a further 201 stateless Vietnamese families comprising 648 people with relatives in Australia remain in the Philippines; (4) notes that the United Kingdom and the United States of America have accepted over 300 people and have indicated a willingness to accept additional stateless Vietnamese people; and (5) calls on the Government to consider compassionately granting humanitarian visas to the remaining stateless Vietnamese families with relatives in Australia. (Notice given 16 November 2004.) Time allotted -30 minutes. Speech time limits Mover of motion -5 minutes. First Government Member speaking -5 minutes. Other Members -5 minutes each. [Proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins] The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day. 4 Mr Randall to move: That this House: (1) acknowledges the profound impact autism has on Australian families and the challenges they face in finding sufficient educational, developmental and respite services to help children and their carers with this life long disability (2) notes that the funding of programs by the States to provide vital support to children with autism is vastly inadequate and causing unnecessary hardship and concern for their families; and; (3) accepts that while the States have primary responsibility for the provision of disability support services, the Federal Government should play an active leadership role in what is a nationwide issue that affects 1 in 1,000 children born in Australia. (Notice given 29 November 2004.) Time allotted - remaining private Members' business time. Speech time limits Mover of motion -5 minutes. First Opposition Member speaking -5 minutes. Other Members -5 minutes each. [Proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins] The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day. NA

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: Sydney) (4.24 p.m.)The Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment 2004 (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004 is an omnibus bill that seeks to implement a range of commitments made by the government during the federal election campaign. The amendments outlined in the legislation are: to create a utilities supplement for senior Australians of age pension or veteran pension age who currently receive income support; to establish a new seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees who hold a Commonwealth seniors health card; to change the eligibility requirements for the carer payment by increasing the number of hours that carers may spend in work, training or study without losing qualification for the carer payment; to create a new special rate of child-care benefit for some grandparents with primary care of their grandchildren, which will cover the full cost of child-care fees; and to extend bereavement payments to widows of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans and ex-servicemen. Of course, Labor will support the measures in this bill, though, as with much of the government's legislation, we are agreeing not because the policy initiatives are strong or because this the best way of dealing with the problems that have been identified but because these measures go a little of the way to ameliorating the deprivations and hardships that this government has created. Specific promises were made during the election campaign, and Labor believe that we have an obligation to ensure that these promises are delivered in full. We will not stand between Australians and the money that was promised to them during the election campaign through these new initiatives, despite their obvious flaws. Of course, one flaw is that the approach taken by the government is incredibly ad hoc and responds to criticisms that the government faced during and before the election campaign about their lack of concern and their lack of compassion for low-income Australians and older Australians. The measures do not represent any philosophy of social welfare, there is no logic to them and they do not reflect how members of the government see a holistic approach to welfare reform. They are ad hoc measures. Many of them are not even targeted at low-income Australians-for example, the seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees is available to Australian couples on retirement incomes of up to $80,000 a year. There are many Australians on pensions-not the age pension-who will not receive a cent through this new omnibus bill. And it certainly seems inconsistent that people on very low incomes, who are earning a fraction of the amount identified in the seniors concession allowance, will not get any benefit at all. Labor believe, instead, that welfare reform of course is necessary and that the government's approach of applying bandaid upon bandaid makes social security in this country less fair and more complex. Our social welfare system should be an integrated structure that is easy to understand and follow, where is eligibility for financial assistance is based on need and incentive, not political quick fix solutions. The government do not understand social security. They are not interested in maintaining a coherent and efficient system that works for people in genuine need. They are only interested in applying bandaids whenever a problem arises. You can see that with the $600 family payment, the $100 utilities supplement and the $200 payment for self-funded retirees. They are all bandaids; they are not long-term solutions for any of the underlying problems that are easy to identify. Instead of making the system simpler, the government continue to make it more complex, because of this approach of applying bandaid upon bandaid. It becomes more complex because each bandaid has a different eligibility test and many of them have different indexation methods. It is very difficult for Centrelink to follow the details, let alone your average Australian. Rather than just applying these bandaids, Labor believe that we should find better and consistent ways of helping people who are feeling financial pressure. Instead of coming up with a one-off payment every time a problem arises, our view is that it would be a lot better to address the fundamental flaws in the system to prevent these problems arising in the first place. I also want to highlight the fact that this government did not bother to properly fund the measures in this bill before its introduction. Certainly, when the measures were foreshadowed during the election campaign, the figures were quite different to what we see at the end. The government's own bean counters in Treasury concluded that the savings that were supposed to fund the initiatives in this bill were overestimated by $130 million. That is a very substantial overestimation. That is a $130 million black hole in the funding of this bill to start with. We have also seen that the government has failed to achieve the savings that it needs to fund the bill. The Minister for Health and Ageing indicated during the election that the government would fund these measures by allocating $700 million of the total it said could be saved from reducing the price paid by government for medicines. Not only has the government failed to achieve these savings, it does not even know how to start going about doing so. It does not know whether legislation is required to make these savings. It does not know what form that legislation would take. It seems to be engaged in headto-head conflict with the pharmaceutical companies at the moment to see what the pharmaceutical companies will cop when it comes to cutting their profits. This debacle raises the spectre of an enormous black hole for the government. The first measure in the bill is the utility supplement for senior Australians. Schedule 1 of the bill creates a new utility supplement for senior Australians by amending a range of Commonwealth legislation, including the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 and the Social Security Act 1991. The new payment is intended to assist senior Australians to pay for regular household bills. Currently, many senior Australians on income support are entitled to receive one of a number of concession cards that provide access to cheaper prescriptions and a range of other benefits. The new payment is intended to provide assistance to older Australians to help them pay for utilities such as gas, electricity and water. The bill provides that all Australians of age pension or veteran pension age who receive income support will be eligible for the new payment. The utility supplement is $100 a year for singles or $50 each for each member of a couple, and it will be subject to the consumer price index. The payment will be paid in two instalments each year, on 20 March and 20 September, starting on 20 March 2005. It strikes me as curious that the government have chosen to index this payment according to the CPI, given that they have admitted in legislation currently before us that they were wrong to index the $600 per child family payment on the basis of CPI. They have admitted that indexing on the basis of CPI leads to a whittling away of a benefit over time and have introduced legislation to fix that with family payments. It is extraordinary then that, at the same time that we have legislation fixing it in the family payments area, we have this small amount of money paid to pensioners to help them with their utilities that the government have chosen to index in exactly the same way that they have agreed is a problem with family payments. The government claims that the new benefit will be paid to 2.2 million senior Australians each year at a cost of $606.4 million over four years. The utility supplement creates two classes of pensioners that are divided simply by age. Australians on a Commonwealth government pension other than the age pension-for example, a disability support pension, a war widow pension, a sole parent pension or a carer pension-are not eligible for this utilities allowance. I find this difficult to comprehend also. Many of these Australians are just as needy as, and some of them perhaps even more needy than, people on age pensions. Qualifying criteria for social security should always be based on need or incentive. It is not good economics and it is not fair social policy to divide people simply by age. Because of the eligibility requirements for the new payment, a carer aged 60 caring for their partner of a similar age with severe disabilities will be treated as less deserving of this extra financial support than an age pensioner couple in a similar situation who are just a few years older. Perhaps the government believes that pensioners who are not of age pension age are somehow less deserving than those who are. But, as I have already indicated, Labor does not intend to prevent eligible age pensioners from benefiting from this legislation to create the utility supplement. It is just worth pointing out the extraordinary anomalies for people who do not qualify simply because of their age. The self-funded retiree payment is covered in schedule 2 of the bill, which establishes a new seniors concession allowance of $200 per annum for self-funded retirees who are eligible for a Commonwealth seniors health card by amending a range of Commonwealth legislation, including the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 and the Social Security Act 1991. The new payment is being made in recognition that many self-funded retirees do not generally receive concessions for energy, rates, water and motor vehicle registration in the same way as some other senior Australians do and to acknowledge the contribution made by self-funded retirees in providing for their own retirement. The bill limits the new cash payment to holders of the Commonwealth seniors health card. Under existing means testing arrangements for this card, the new payment will be available to retirees with adjusted taxable incomes of less than $50,000 per annum for singles and $80,000 per annum combined for couples. The government proposes to make this payment on 1 December and 1 June each year, starting with a $200 payment on 1 December 2004. Again, this payment is subject to CPI indexation and, again, I make the point that the government admitted in the family payments debacle that CPI indexation is not appropriate because it does whittle away the value of these cash payments over time. It seems extraordinary to me that, at very same time that we are fixing one payment through one piece of legislation, the government is introducing another piece of legislation that is subject to the same problem. I wonder whether the government will have to come back in a few weeks time or next week and fix this indexation problem here. The government estimates that 287,000 self-funded retirees will receive the new payment, at a cost of $255.2 million over four years. Of course Labor supports any measure which makes life a little bit easier for people who are living on fixed incomes, but it is difficult to understand the logic of this haphazard response to cost-of-living issues for older Australians. It is not clear from the legislation whether the government intends for both parties in self-funded retiree couples to receive the new $200 payment. I imagine that it is not the intention of the government, but the legislation certainly does not make clear that it is not the intention. It is inconsistent with the government's treatment of the utilities allowance, which is available to couples at the single rate. The utilities allowance cannot simply be claimed twice by both members of the pensioner couple, yet it is not clear whether this payment cannot be claimed twice by a self-funded retiree couple. So in the same bill we have completely different policy approaches on display. Australian couples of a certain age on income support can receive a maximum of $50 for each member of a couple towards utilities expenses-in total the couple gets the same as single Australians of pension age-but self-funded retiree couples who have healthcare cards can possibly each claim $200 per year to help pay for the same things. They get double the benefit that a single self-funded retiree gets and double the benefit available to older Australian couples on in the come support. It creates a very inequitable result, because Australian couples of pension age get half the new utilities allowance each, whereas self-funded retirees in a couple may get double the payment that single self-funded retirees are entitled to. These payments also stand in stark contrast to the Treasurer's criticisms of Labor's Medicare Gold package. The Treasurer continues to claim that benefits paid to older Australians will naturally blow out because we have an ageing population, yet his own government introduces new measures that are aimed at exactly the same age group and that are certainly not subject to particularly stringent means testing. Schedule 3 of the bill amends section 198C of the Social Security Act 1991 to change the eligibility requirements for the carer payment by increasing the number of hours that carers can spend in work, training or study without losing their qualification for the carer payment. Currently, people who are caring for an adult or a child with a disability and who receive the carer payment are not disqualified from that payment if they temporarily cease providing care in order to undertake training, education, unpaid voluntary work or paid employment, but the maximum length of time has been 20 hours. That is being increased to 25 hours. On the face of it, it is a perfectly good measure. Labor certainly supports any measures that allow carers to re-engage in the work force, to work as volunteers, to get training or to get an education. It is worth noting, though, that, while this bill increases the number of hours that a carer can work, it does not change the income test for the carer payment. So, if carers work an extra five hours at the minimum wage of $12.30 an hour and get an extra $61.50 in income, they lose $24.60 in pension, because the pension cuts out at 40c for every dollar earned. When you include the $24.60 that they are losing in pension, plus what they lose in tax, it really does not make it particularly worthwhile for carers to pick up a bit of work, training or education that may help them into the work force at a later time. The government likes to give with one hand and take back with the other. The next measure is the child-care benefit changes for grandparents. These are covered in schedule 4 of the bill, which amends the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act 1999 and the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Act 1999 to improve child-care assistance for grandparents in receipt of income support who have primary care responsibilities for grandchildren. This means that grandparents who have primary care of a grandchild or grandchildren and who are receiving income support will be entitled to a special rate of child-care benefit. That special rate of child-care benefit will cover the full cost of child-care fees charged to eligible grandparents by approved child-care services. The government estimates that this change will cost $76.4 million over four years, and it hopes to commence eligibility from January 2005. Of course we support these measures as far as they go. We had a much more comprehensive package for grandparents before the election campaign, and we believe that these changes do not go far enough. We support any extra assistance given to grandparents, but it is worth noting that this extra assistance only goes to grandparents who have their children in approved care, which means predominantly long day care or family day care. There will be a vast number of grandparents who have care of their grandchildren and will not benefit at all from these measures. This includes grandparents who are using registered carers, either because they are more conveniently located or because the children already have a strong relationship with those carers. Most likely, it will be because grandparents, like many Australian parents, simply cannot find child care for their grandchildren. The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimated that in June 2002and these are the most recent comprehensive figures that we have-there was a national shortage of 174,500 child-care places. It is plain that grandparents will be on same long waiting lists and will be facing the same difficulties in finding places for grandchildren that parents face in finding places for their children. That is certainly the case for grandparents who live in rural areas, in parts of regional Australia and in parts of urban Australia. Indeed, in my own electorate, I think one estimate is that there are children on child-care waiting lists in one suburb, Erskineville. It is plain that many grandparents will not receive any assistance at all. They, of course, are struggling through in the same way as grandparents who do manage to find child care in long day care centres or in family day care for the children that they care for. impossible to know how many grandparents are in this group that will not benefit at all, because of course there are no figures kept by the government on grandparents who would be seeking care for their grandchildren but who have given up being able to find it. The contrast, of course, is with Labor's proposal before the election campaign to give every grandparent who had caring responsibilities for their grandchildren $20 per week for each child in their care. The government proposes to spend $76 million over four years; our proposal was to spend $144 million over the same period-almost double-in helping grandparents who have responsibility for caring for grandchildren. That is the sort of help that grandparents need, and it is the sort of help that this does not deliver. It does not deliver any versal assistance for grandparents at all in recognition of the massive public service they perform in raising happy, healthy children. Labor's commitment was a recognition that grandparents have already sacrificed much to raise their own children and that many are now on fixed or low incomes and the struggling to raise grandchildren as well. It is also important to note that the government got the costings of this policy wrong during the election campaign. The estimate during the election campaign was $70 million. This bill contains the official estimate of $78.6 million over four years to deliver this special rate of child-care benefit. So that 500 is a difference of almost $9 million, more than 10 per cent off the mark. Given that the government's estimate included the cost of waiving the work, study or training test for grandparents to access child-care benefit, this is another example of the sort of dodgy figures that the coalition pull out of their hat at election time. The government's boast of It is economic responsibility is completely undermined by these sorts of chronic underestimations of costs at election time, which are subsequently made up when they return to parliament. The other thing worth noting here is that the Minister for Family and Community Services herself said: Up to 16,000 grandparents who have the primary responsibility for raising and caring for a grandchild may now be entitled to additional support through Child Care Benefit ... That change has been made by waiving the work or study test for grandparent carers. It has been done as an administrative change; it has not come before the parliament as legislation. So the estimates do not include the extra 16,000 grandparents who will now be eligible for the maximum rate of child-care bill benefit because of the waiver of the work, uni- study or training test-a change that was made just a few weeks ago by executive decision. That is yet more evidence that the government did not do its sums before coming up with these policies. At the conclusion of my comments I will move an amendment that relates to the issue of grandparents' eligibility for child-care benefit. Before I do so, I will mention that schedule 5 of the bill honours an election commitment to extend bereavement payments to widows of TPI veterans and ex-servicemen. The current provisions for bereavement payments are that six fortnightly payments are made to surviving partners. The bill will extend these payments to include all payments in excess of the general rate. This will benefit surviving partners of 28½ thousand TPIs and 15,000 extremely disabled veterans. The cost is $14.8 million over four years. Labor of course supports that extension. I will now go on to the second reading amendment that I foreshadowed. I move: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House: (1) notes that under the proposals contained in this Bill grandparent carers who are receiving income support will have access to a special rate of benefit, but this will only be available to those grandparents who use approved child care services; (2) acknowledges that under the proposals in this Bill grandparents who use registered child care providers will receive no benefit whatsoever; and (3) condemns the Government for its inequitable treatment of those grandparents who use registered childcare providers and notes that the Government has failed to ensure the reasonable availability of approved child care services”.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
