text: Is the amendment seconded? Ms Gillard-I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: I rise to support the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004. The measures contained in this bill will assist many older people and carers in my electorate of Makin and across Australia. Importantly, they honour the commitments we made during the recent election campaign. We owe a debt of gratitude to our older Australians, many of whom have fought in wars in the defence of this country. They helped to make Australia the great place it is today, which is why they deserve the assistance and support we are providing in this bill. We also recognise the changing nature of Australian society. It is a fact that there are an increasing number of grandparents who are the prime carers of their grandchildren, for whatever reason. It could be because the parents are absent or, sadly, because the parents are incapable of looking after their children due to alcohol or illicit drug addiction. On many occasions, while out door-knocking and on Saturday morning electorate visits, I met many grandparents who were struggling that because of the need to look after their grandchildren. There are measures in this bill which will be of assistance to them. It has been estimated that over one-fifth of children below school age in Australia are cared for by their grandparents as part of the family's regular child-care arrangements. In 2003 the government, through the Department of Family and Community Services, commissioned the Council on the Ageing and the National Seniors Association to undertake a project entitled Grandparents Raising Grandchildren. The focus of the project was on talking to grandparents who are raising their grandchildren, to discover what support mechanisms they require and the financial and legal issues they face. An extensive Australia-wide public consultation process was followed, with the aim of gaining a clear picture of the needs and requirements of these seniors. One of the issues raised by many grandparents was access to and the affordability of child care. The government announced during the election campaign that it would provide assistance to grandparents who are raising their grandchildren and bearing the costs of child care. This bill honours that commitment. From 3 January 2004, grandparents who are on income support and who are the principal carers of their own grandchildren will receive free approved child care under a special rate of child-care benefit to be known as the grandparent child-care benefit. The government has recognised that many grandparents who are the prime carers of their grandchildren have limited means of accessing quality child care. It is a fact that most of these seniors never expected to find themselves in the situation of being full-time carers for their grandchildren and are therefore ill prepared for the costs associated with this responsibility. Nevertheless, as the COTA National Seniors project discovered, they are committed to providing the love and care that their grandchildren need. In a very real sense, they are the silent heroes of our nation. Having given so much already, they continue to give to the next generation. To ensure that all children in the grandparent carer's immediate family are treated the same, the government will provide free approved child care to other children in the grandparent carer's own family, provided the grandparents' grandchild is also attending approved child care. Eligibility for this benefit will also include great-grandparents as well as those in adoptive or step relationships, so long as they are the principal carers. Grandparent carers will be able to claim up to 50 hours of the grandparent child-care benefit per child per week. This follows the waiver of the work, training and study test for grandparent carers, which was introduced on 1 November 2004. Grandparent carers will also be able to request additional hours of free child care in exceptional circumstances, such as hospitalisation. Before moving on to the other measures contained in this bill, I want to advise the House of the Grandparents for Grandchildren South Australia group that has been established in my home state. The chief aim of this group is to promote the role and needs of grandparents raising their grandchildren. A new support group has been established at Modbury Heights in my electorate, and I wish to congratulate those involved, particularly Mrs Kerry Forster, who has worked very hard to bring this to fruition. The group produces a very interesting newsletter entitled The Coffee Break, which is full of information that would be of assistance to seniors who are caring for their grandchildren. A new payment is to be established with the passage of this bill, which will be known as the utilities allowance. Despite the promises made by the Rann Labor government in South Australia to bring down the price of electricity, chiefly because of the national power grid deal that we had to have, courtesy of Messrs Keating and John Bannon-just like the recession we had to have-the cost of electricity continues to rise. People are hurting, and this is particularly so among the elderly. The utilities allowance will go some way to alleviating the burden by providing a payment of $100 per year for singles and $50 per year for each member of a couple. People of pension age who are in receipt of income support will be eligible to receive the utilities allowance. Importantly, the allowance is to be linked to the consumer price index to ensure that the value of the payment, in real terms, is protected. This bill also honours another ernment's election commitments through the establishment of the senior's concession allowance. Self-funded retirees miss out on many of the concessions available to pensioners for such things as water and sewerage rates and motor vehicle registration from state and territory governments. Despite the states and territories receiving a huge windfall gain from the GST revenue, which goes entirely to them, they are unwilling to pass on the benefits to their communities. I am constantly amazed by the buck-passing that goes on. If you listened to a South Australian state government minister speaking, you could be forgiven for thinking that they have absolutely no responsibility for anything. If there is a problem, it is always some other level of government's responsibility. If there is a solution, they will not fund it. And, if there is to be any kudos, then and only then do they wish to participate. It is the federal government which is now introducing the $200 a year seniors concession allowance to holders of the Commonwealth seniors health card. This payment will also be linked to the CPI. This payment is aimed squarely at helping self-funded retirees, who deserve some relief and support for the contribution they have made to providing for their retirement. The government is also to be commended for another new measure, contained in this bill, which provides for more flexibility for carer payment customers by increasing the time a carer can work, train or study without losing eligibility for payment from 20 to 25 hours per week. Carers play a vital role in our community and save the taxpayers millions of dollars each year. This new measure will provide carers with more opportunities to undertake work, training or study and will assist them in the development and/or maintenance of skills for present or future work of the gov- force participation. In the area of veterans affairs, the government is increasing the bereavement payment for spouses of veterans from 1 January 2005. From that date, spouses of veterans who were receiving a disability pension at the special rate for the totally and permanently incapacitated at the intermediate rate or for extreme disablement will receive a bereavement payment to the equivalent of six payments of the veterans above general rate disability pension. I am pleased to support this bill because, as I have said, it will benefit the people I represent, the people of Makin. Equally, it provides yet one more reason why the coalition government was returned to office with the support of the majority of Australians. At the very beginning of the recent campaign, the Prime Minister made it clear that the election was about trust. Who could the Australian people trust to deliver a strong and growing economy? Who would the Australian people trust to provide more jobs and reduce unemployment? Who would create the right environment to keep interest rates low and encourage home ownership? Who would Australians trust to protect them, as much as possible, from international terrorism? As this bill clearly demonstrates, the Australian people can also trust the government to deliver on our election commitments. We promised the measures contained in this bill and, with the support of the parliament, we will deliver.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: Lalor) (5.01 p.m.)Madam Deputy Speaker Bishop, I commence my contribution by congratulating you on becoming a member of the Speaker's panel. I understand this is the first time you have sat in the chair, and there have been some photographers in the gallery interested in marking the moment. We are aware that you were, at an earlier point in time, hoping to occupy the chair more frequently. You certainly had some supporters on this side of the House in that regard, but it is good to you in the chair now. As my colleague the member for Sydney has outlined Labor's position on the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004, I will turn to a series of associated matters. This bill is about creating a utility supplement for senior Australians of age pension or veterans pension age who currently receive income support. It is about establishing a new seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees who hold a Commonwealth seniors health card. It is about changing the eligibility requirements for carer payments by increasing the number of hours that carers may spend in work, training or study without losing qualification for carer payments. It is about creating a new special rate of child-care benefit for grandparents with primary care of their grandchildren, which will cover the full cost of childcare fees, and it is about extending the bereavement payments to widows of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans and ex-servicemen. As the member for Sydney has outlined, it is not our intention to delay passage of this bill and to hold up the payment of benefits to people in these categories. But I feel it task to outline to the House that this bill comes associated with a trifecta of double standards. The first of those double standards flows from much of the work that Treasurer Costello has done on the question of intergenerational equity and intergenerational costs. Treasurer Costello is very proud of having commissioned the Intergenerational Report, which came with the budget papers. He is also very proud, as we have heard as recently as last week and in this chamber yesterday, of having referred to the Productivity Commission the question of the impact of the ageing of Australia's population. The draft report from the Productivity see Commission was released last Thursday. As we would expect, there is nothing new or highly original about these statistics, but the Productivity Commission went on to conclude that there will be a major impact of ageing on government revenue and on demands for government services. We know that by 2042 Australia's population is projected to increase by around 30 per cent to over 25 million and that the number of people aged over 55 will grow faster than the number of people aged under 55. There are currently around 15 million people aged under 55 and slightly more than four million people aged over 55. By 2042 there will be 16 million people aged under 55 and over nine million people aged over 55. This change in the demographics of the Australian population, according to the Productivity Commission, will open up a gap between revenue and outlays at both the state and federal levels in the order of seven per cent in 40 years time. The Treasurer publicly and in this place consistently points to his concerns about the impact of ageing on our society and its impact on government outlays and demands for government services. As recently as yesterday the Treasurer was in this House criticisis my ing Labor's Medicare Gold policy on this basis. As it turns out, the criticisms that the Treasurer made of the Medicare Gold policy are quite erroneous, because Medicare Gold, as well as being a package which would benefit people over 75, is actually a health efficiency measure which would save between $500 million and $600 million each year. That is the amount wasted each year now because the Commonwealth government funds aged care while the states administer the public hospitals, and so there is no signal in the system to make the Commonwealth make available the right number of aged care beds. That shows up in state administered public hospitals with frail Austrawhat lians who could be in an aged care institution or in some other form of care ending up being accommodated in acute public hospital beds because there is nowhere else for them to go. As we all know, there is nothing more expensive in our health system than an acute hospital bed. Medicare Gold would resolve that problem and save between $500 million and $600 million a year. It would get out of the system the cost shifting and buck passing that currently happens between the Commonwealth and the states on the question of care of older Australians and, with the Commonwealth as a monopoly purchaser of hospital services for older Australians, it would drive efficiencies across the public and private sectors. The Treasurer is right to ask: what is the intergenerational impact of Medicare Gold? We know what the intergenerational impact of Medicare Gold is because it has been modelled for the Labor Party by experts, and the experts say that over 40 years the cost Medicare Gold to this country would decrease as a percentage of GDP. This is in circumstances where the Productivity Commission tells us that if health care costs dealt with as they are now then as a percentage of GDP they will blow out from six per cent-as they are now-to 10.8 per cent of GDP by 2044-45. The Treasurer is always on about the impact of ageing but he is basically administering a health care system in which we are expecting to see an enormous increase in government outlays as a percentage of GDP. Medicare Gold, because it is an efficiency measure, would actually as a percentage of GDP cost less over time. So we have the efficiencies of Medicare Gold on display against the inefficiency of the current system. We have picked up the challenge and we have been prepared to model the intergenerational consequences of Medicare Gold. But stands in stark contrast to all of the Treasurer's rhetoric is the failure of the government to model the intergenerational consequences for older Australians of its various promises in the recent election campaign. In this package there is a utility supplement for senior Australians of age pension or veteran pension age who currently receive income support. By definition that is a growing class of Australians. What is the cost of that? What will that be as a percentage of GDP in 20 years or 40 years time? Where is the intergenerational modelling on that? What are the consequences of that promise for revenue outlays of the Commonwealth with all of the implications about budget deficit or taxation arrangements? If the Treasurer has that intergenerational modelling then we would like to see it. If he wants to say to Labor that we should model the intergenerational consequences, it is a double standard not to do it himself. He ought to be producing in this House the intof ergenerational modelling of the costs of the utility supplement. And what is the intergenerational cost of the new seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees who hold a are Commonwealth seniors health care card? What is that going to cost as a percentage of GDP in 20 or 40 years time? Where is the intergenerational modelling on that? If it has not been done then how can the Treasurer hold out this government as one that is looking at the challenge of ageing in a way which will ensure that the costs of ageing do not get out of control in Australia? If it has not been done then the Treasurer's words stand revealed as the most empty and hollow of rhetoric. If it has been done, where is it? While we are on the question of intergenerational modelling, where is the modelling of the mooted changes to the private health insurance rebate for older Australians? What is that going to cost as a percentage of GDP in 20 or 40 years time? I know that is not within the ambit of this bill, but it will be dealt with later this week. The Treasurer gives all the signs of being a man who is serious about the policy question of ageing. He displays a great deal of pride about the Intergenerational Report with the budget papers, a great deal of pride about putting these matters on the COAG agenda and a great deal of pride about referring it to the Productivity Commission. He is Mr Ageing. He says he is going to deal with this challenge. If he is going to deal with challenge then he will deal with it in each and every piece of legislation and expenditure item proposed by this government for older Australians. There are two in this bill. The intergenerational modelling of this package should be produced before this debate ends. That is the first double standard that informs this bill. I will describe the second double standard that informs this bill. We listen day after day in question time to various government ministers talking about their record of fiscal sponsibility. The topic of how fiscally responsible the Howard government is is often used in this parliament. One wonders some days how they can maintain that pretence of fiscal responsibility having spent $66 billion in promises associated with winning the recent election and having spent $6 billion on the Prime Minister's campaign launch. They maintain that pretence of fiscal responsibility. In line with that pretence, how is the $130 million black hole in this package going to be covered? The government, having spent $6 billion on the Prime Minister's campaign launch and $66 billion in total in the run-up to the election and on election promises, then got startled by Labor's Medicare Gold. It had until that point intended to skate through the election campaign taking the votes of older Australians for granted. The Prime Minister was proceeding on the political strategy that he already had the votes of older Australians in his back pocket so, out of a $66 billion spend, senior Australians did not need a cent spent on them. Then the Leader of the Opposition announced Medicare Gold on 29 September in his campaign launch and the Prime Minister went into a campaign bunker and did not emerge for two days. He knew then that the game was up. He knew then that he could this not take the votes of senior Australians for granted. His polling would have been showing him that in spades. But he knew as well that his fiscal credibility had been torn to shreds by the $6 billion spend in his campaign speech, that the financial press was laughing at him and that he was receiving very bad publicity for this in the mainstream media. So he was in a dilemma. He had taken the votes of senior Australians for granted and he then needed to do something about them because the polling had gone bad re- post-Medicare Gold. What was he going to do? He had to cobble together a savings measure to support this package so he quickly did that, only to find when the Department of Finance and Administration modelled the savings measure that it was $130 million short. Where is the $130 million that is needed to fund the black hole in this package coming from? That is another question that this government needs to answer before we finally deal with this legislation. Almost more breathtaking than those two double standards is the double standard associated with the savings measure that supports this bill. It is breathtaking. The savings measure is a series of changes to listing and pricing arrangements for generic drugs and an increase in the efficiency dividend from one per cent to 1.25 per cent-that is, savings measures associated with the expenditure on this bill are being generated by changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. You say to yourself, ‘If there were hundreds of millions of dollars of savings that could be responsibly taken from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, why didn't the government find it earlier, given that government was advocating a price hike of 30 per cent in the price of essential medicines?' As a consequence of the Intergenerational Report about which I have spoken, the Treasurer came into this place and went to the Australian community and said: ‘The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is not sustainable in the face of ageing. We have to do something about it. I know what we are going to do: we are going to put up the price of essential medicines by 30 per cent and put that burden on Australians when they are required to make a copayment for their essential medicines.' It was Labor that at that point said: ‘Hang on Treasurer; we are as interested as you in the long-term sustainability of the PBS and we understand that its long-term sustainability is under pressure because of ageing and because of the innovation of new and expensive drugs. We understand that. We're more wedded to the PBS than you are, Treasurer, because we actually invented it.' So Labor said: ‘We understand the problem, Treasurer, but we think there is a better way to fix it than putting the price of essential medicines up by 30 per cent for all Australians. We think the better way to fix it is to look for savings based around listing arrangements and pricing arrangements in the PBS.' That is exactly what we said to the government. What did the government say to us? For years it said nothing. It did not bor's offer to explore these hundreds of millions of dollars of savings which could be made on the PBS. It did not say anything. Finally, in frustration, the then shadow Treasurer, Bob MCMullan, the member for Fraser, and I wrote to our respective counterparts-he of course writing to the Minister for Finance and Administration, and me writing to the Minister for Health and Ageingthe asking for information about the potential savings that could be generated on the PBS. We said we wanted to use those savings to offset the need for the 30 per cent price hike in the cost of essential medicines. Here is what the Minister for Finance and Administration wrote back: A fundamental principle in the construction of budget and forward estimates for the PBS is that the fiscal impact of new listings on the PBS are not included in the Budget aggregates until there is certainty about both when they will come onto the market and the price that will be charged. He goes on: Given this principle, I consider that it would be inappropriate to make any form of speculative provision in the forward estimates for the effect of generic drugs coming on to the PBS in advance of any of these steps having been completed. Should such a provision be contemplated, it would be necessary, for reasons of consistency, to also include an estimate of the potential future listings of new, patented, high cost drugs. If this approach were to be taken, I consider that PBS forward estimates would become so speculative as to be meaningless. So, in the face of Labor saying, ‘We think there are hundreds of millions of dollars of savings on the PBS,' the Minister for Finance and Administration from the self-styled fiscally responsible Howard government said, ‘No, no, no; if we did that on the forward estimates it would make the forward estimates so speculative as to be meaningless.' Ms Plibersek-We wouldn't know how take up La- much we were saving.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: No, we would not know how much we were saving or how much we were being required to spend on new branded drugs. Apparently, what is meaningless when it is sent in June in a letter from the minister for finance to our then shadow Treasurer becomes full of meaning on an election day when the Howard government needs a few hundred million dollars of savings to support a measure for older Australians because it is getting a vote bleed from older Australians due to Medicare Gold. So it is meaningless in June-it would render the forward estimates speculative; it would be the end of fiscal responsibility and management as we know it in Australia-but, of course, two days after Labor's campaign launch, it can be done and these savings can be booked, and they have been booked to support this measure short $130 million. Honestly, some days you have just got to shake your head in wonderment about the double standards, backflips and arrogance exhibited by the government. What did they think? Did they think that no-one would notice that for a couple of years they denied that there were these savings-they denied in writing that they were available-and they suddenly found them a week out from the election? Did they think no-one was going to notice that? They are so arrogant they think people forget what happened yesterday. We have not forgotten, and let me tell you who else has not forgotten: the pharmaceutical industry has not forgotten. The pharmaceutical industry is rightly asking how this is going to be done. Where is the legislation to implement the changes? If the expenditure starts on 1 ary, don't the savings have to flow from 1 January? Isn't this the last two sitting weeks before 1 January? Where is the bill? Does anybody have an answer to that question? Where is the bill? How are you going to start on 1 January spending money that you do not have? Where is the bill? Second, is it possible to mandate a 12.5 per cent decrease in PBS medicines? Has anybody looked at that? Not as far as I am aware. Where is the modelling and data to support the government's claimed PBS savings-the savings that they said could not be found-and what will the impact of the increased efficiency dividend be on the Public Service? That is not a PBS saving but it is actually a saving that is booked here too. So we have a government that denied for years, and denied in writing, the existence of these savings now relying on them. Having put itself in a position where it is going to start spending on 1 January, it appears to have no clue-to be completely cluelessabout how it is going to generate these savings in time to match the expenditure. So something I would really like to hear from the Treasurer or the Minister for Health and Ageing before the conclusion of this debate is where these savings are coming from; when they are going to be implemented; what the details are; and what consultation the government has had with the pharmaceutical industry. If the answer to that is blank looks-and I suspect it will be-then this government has to explain how it can try to maintain its so-called credentials for being a fiscally responsible government in the face of this gross fiscal irresponsibility. I suggest that it stop criticising other people's policies on that basis until it amends its own. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: Bowman) (5.21 p.m.)The Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Janu- (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004, which we are debating today, will amend the social security law, the family assistance law and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 to give effect to certain commitments made during the election campaign just gone. The benefits will flow to self-funded retirees, to older Australians, to grandparents caring for children and to certain disability pensioners. Obviously we are keen to see those measures passed as soon as possible to ensure that older Australians continue to receive the assistance that they so deserve under the strong economic management of this government. There are five measures in this bill and I begin with the $200 seniors concession allowance paid to all holders of the Commonwealth seniors health care card. This payment recognises that self-funded retirees do not receive from state and territory governments discounts on power, rates, water and sewerage, nor do they receive such discounts very often on motor vehicle registration. But it also recognises that this group has made a considerable contribution in providing for their own retirement. Many in my electorate of Bowman have said, ‘It's appropriate, it's welcomed and I'm glad that we are not forgotten by this government.' That payment comes in two instalments to eligible cardholders: on 1 December and on 1 June. Secondly, the bill establishes the new $100 utility allowance payable to senior Australians of age pension age or veteran pension age who are in receipt of income support. This payment will help that group to pay for regular household bills such as gas and electricity. In general, that will be $100 per year, or $50 for each member of a couple. Together those payments will benefit over two million Australians who continue to contribute to Australia and to their own futures. Both payments will be indexed twice yearly, both will be tax exempt and both will be payable even if the citizen is overseas for up to 13 weeks of the year. Constituents in Bowman have said to me that it is often very difficult to plan ahead, particularly for utilities, while one is living on a pension-and I point out that the pension does fall from $775 per fortnight for a couple to $464 for a single. This is often a concern for singles who are living alone. Many feel that that fall of $8,086 per year is hardly representative of a cost difference between living in a single or double household. So they are very delighted that that payment will be to a household, regardless of how many pensioners are living there. It is interesting to hear the member for Sydney say that there is an additional complexity or an additional administrative layer. Certainly to deliver a payment like this for utilities on a week-by-week basis would be completely counterproductive. The very purpose of the payment is to make it easier to plan ahead and meet those obligations. I cannot see any other way of doing it except as an intermittent payment. But also to view this payment as a bandaid is to completely miss the point because 5.2 per cent of Australians now do not have to rely on bandaids-they are gainfully employed in the economy. That means there are a lot of bandaids left over to give to those who truly deserve that assistance in their senior years. That allows people planning their final years to have the security and support to pay for such things as utilities. In the case of the $200 payment, it is given to two individuals in a household, obviously because it covers power, rates, water and, at times, registration for more than one vehicle. A number of costs accrue to such a family and it is entirely appropriate that there should be a payment to each individual. The bill also allows for child care to be more affordable for grandparents who are carers and receiving income support such as an age pension or a carer payment. The special rate provided for in this bill will cover the full cost of child-care places charged to eligible grandparents by approved child-care providers. I would like to shed some light on a key part of this bill, the disability portion. This bill will provide additional support for people who care for an adult or a child with disability. That group of people perform a vital role in our community. Increasing the amount of hours that they can dedicate to either work or further study, and therefore have a break from the often very onerous role of caring for a relative, is a good thing, and being still eligible for the carer payment is a very important part of that. But I want to put a family face on the dilemma of accessing respite. We have a number of couples and families in my electorate in that position. One is a single mum of 55 years of age. She has a severely disabled son living at home at the age of 17 who has Cornelia de Lange syndrome. This is a fairly rare condition, first described in the 1930s. It multiple congenital anomaly syndrome which affects both feeding and behaviour. It can lead to severe epilepsy, severe malformations of the upper limbs, scoliosis, osteoporosis and psychomotor disorders, which can make it extremely difficult for the person to leave the house, have an excursion or even go shopping with a carer. The family is one of nature's great masterpieces, so can there be any greater contribution than family members dedicating their life to caring for other family members who need almost day-today, hour-to-hour support for almost everything they do to meet their basic needs? Currently in Queensland a family in this situation receives not 20, not 10 nor five but 3½ hours of respite a week. The purchase of additional respite is $27 an hour, and 50 per cent more expensive on weekends. When this young boy turned 13 he no longer had access to the Special Needs Subsidy Scheme, which provided two days a week of assistance at vacation care. Once he had turned 16, the income arrangements changed to where he now receives $400 a fortnight and his mum receives a carer payment of $375 a fortnight. Mum is forced to do extra work where she can and extending the period she can work by 20 hours to 25 is extremely valuable for her. But there is a catch. For her to be able to access and utilise and enjoy 25 hours, we need a state government that will provide adequate respite care. I seek the indulgence of the chamber to at least acquaint ourselves with a report released just last week: Disability support services 2002-03. That report contains a stateby-state comparison. I am cautious about my comments and I must say that the first chapter following the introduction is about the quality of the data, which has been collected only over six months-but it is the best we is a have at the moment. What we have here is a possible reason why in Queensland it is so hard to access respite care and to be able to enjoy 25 hours a week of either study or work. This mum, who cares for her severely disabled son who is unable to leave the house, is perhaps able to work on a special school bus and take her son to school and back and earn $300 a fortnight on top of the allowance, but there is very little option above that for any quality respite that is affordable. This bill makes those improvements from a Commonwealth level but, as this document will show, there is an extremely restricted supply of respite care in Queensland. So to start with that analysis and summarise it, it is obvious that the prevalence of disability will be somewhat homogenous across states, although small variations will exist. If we look at the number of people accessing disability services, there is a considerably lower level in Queensland than in other states. That is partly explainable by the demographics of the state, but you would expect there to be some policy response to that. Let us see if it occurs. When it comes to the number of people accessing respite care as a proportion of the population, the level in Queensland is at least 10 per cent lower than in comparable states-and about half that in Victoria. The number of outlets are down as well, and the number of people accessing each of these outlets for disability services not 6,600 as in New South Wales or 6,100 as in Victoria but a whopping 8,890 people per outlet. Further, for centre based care, which is a direct responsibility of state governments, there are 117 centres in New South Wales, 136 in Victoria and 51 in Queensland. That is clearly not a policy response to the demographics of a large and decentralised state. The number of people in Queensland trying to access each of these centres is not 56,000 or 35,000 as in other states but 72,500 per respite centre. In the social sector there is only one true measure of commitment, and that is in resources. In respite dollars per capita, we see approximately $8.76 per head as the national average. Queensland is once again well below that at $8.20, and a separate analysis performed independently showed that Queensland has the second lowest average of all states. Disability support money from the states is $906 million and $851 million in the larger states but $325 million in Queensland. This is well down, and the support payment per head of population is $136 in one state, $175 in another, $120 or above in every state but Queensland, which has a support payment of $88 per person. So it was doubly barefaced then for the Queensland government to put out a press release in the middle of last year that indicated there was going to be a boost to funding which had not been included in this report. It is important to try to figure those ditional resources in, even though it is cheating a little because we are not looking at what the other states have also committed. Even when you add in the new commitments from the Queensland government, you see that they are still well below the national average for disability and respite funding. The final line of the press release on respite care said: ‘Families are at the forefront of this government's reform agenda for disabilis ity services.' Families at the forefront-isn't that revolutionary policy formulation? Isn't it breathtakingly underwhelming? Commitment can only be measured in dollars, and we have here a reform agenda for the government. Perhaps Queensland should begin its reform agenda by committing as many dollars per head of population and per user as every other state does. It does not seem to be that complex. Queensland families can be forgiven for a touch of despair when it comes to accessing respite care, and I have made that divarication because it underpins why it is so difficult in Queensland to actually be able to benefit from any increase in eligibility for carers payments. It is one thing for a state government to cast itself as the friend of the disabled but quite another to then starve disability services for 2½ election terms and then crow about having crawled back to the national average or only just. The real issue-the bottleneck, the stumbling blockhere is the state's unwillingness to satisfactorily fund respite services. We have a number of families in my electorate who cannot even place their own child in work experience, which obviously is unpaid-in, for example, a pet shop-because they have to pay $30 an hour for the respite carer to accompany their child to work. As one mum said, ‘Our children don't cause us as much stress as the system and trying to get some help.' I have been provided with a bundle of coradrespondence from mums on trying to deal with Disability Services Queensland. While I commend the individual workers within the department, I have here a complete record of the frustrations of one mum trying to find support from her own state department. So it is interesting that Queensland only now is embarking on measures to increase respite funding when the GST revenues are also just beginning to flow. But the memories of families with disabled members will be long in Queensland, even though they only have 3½ hours of respite care in which to contemplate them. Currently, this is a key impediment for Bowman families, preventing them from fully benefiting from the alterations to the carers payments we are speaking of here today. I commend this bill and each of its five parts.

Speaker: Mr HATTON
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: Blaxland) (5.35 p.m.)Mr Deputy Speaker Beazley, as this is the first occasion, to my knowledge, that I have been in the chamber while you have occupied the chair as a member of the Speaker's panel, may I congratulate you on your election to this office. As you have done in other appointments in the House, you will add lustre to the position.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: Thank you very much. The view is very good from here.

Speaker: Mr HATTON
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: The opposition, led today by the member for Sydney, has indicated it will support each and every one of the measures in the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004, which covers a suite of different election promises that the government is attempting to put in place through this House and the other place. But the member for Sydney has moved an amendment which goes to the core of not just how adequate but how fair and equitable at least one of these changes is. The government has moved to recognise grandparents providing care if they have the full charge and responsibility of a child. It has said that one group of grandparents looking after a child who can get access to approved child care should be given a benefit, so there is a case to be made - and we believe a compelling one-that a group not able to gain access to approved child care, which is then forced to go to a registered child-care place, should also get this benefit. Is there anything in the nature or circumstances of people in the second group that makes them less of a person, carer or grandparent in comparison to people who have been able to get an approved child-care place? We do not believe so. In putting this amendment forward the member for Sydney, as our shadow minister, has rightly argued that if you are going to put in this form of payment you must be fair and make sure that it is available to all grandparents in that position. It should be given to both grandparents and to an approved or a registered child-care place. I support that amendment completely. This is an omnibus bill. It has a range of measures, some of which I will speak to in more detail than others. This range of measures has a context, and well do we know itthere was an election recently. In that recent election in October the government put a series of proposals to the electorate. Indeed, there is an even broader context. Since the budget, which was brought down in the middle of May this year, there has been an even broader fiscal question about how much money is being pumped into this economy through the budget. Originally, I think it was in the order of $37 billion. The mark-up was at least $37 billion of stimulus. If we look at it again it is probably $50 billion worth of stimulus. In just a single day the member for Bennelong-despite his 4.3 per cent buffer in that seat-promised $6 billion worth of benefit to electors from one end of the country to the other, not only in his electorate but in every electorate. The sorts of measures that he was promising in the areas of caring and child-care places were announced for the benefit of people in his electorate, as well as others. What was the grand total? Some people say that it was $50 billion plus $6 billion. In our calculations the all-up total was $66 billion worth of funding in one year. In January and February of 2001 the coalition was in a bit of trouble. From memory, it spent in the order of $21 billion from the budget through to the election period, and it added to that in the election itself. Remarkably, we still have a low-inflation economy, despite the fact that this government has been in power. It tripled the amount of money spent in order to buy its way into office. Introducing a stimulus of $66 billion into the economy in one year has rightly been regarded by most economic commentators in this country as profoundly wrong and dangerous. The great irony in this election was that the government's greatest weaknesses were the ones that helped it get re-elected. Of course, the member for Brand would well know that that irony has not only visited us once. So too, the coalition's greatest weakness in 2001the fact that over 2½ years 13,000 people came illegally into Australia by boatbecame its strength. This is a government of inversions. It takes its great weakness, turns it upside down and campaigns on it very effectively by spending hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money informing us about its general programs and pushing specific programs. But then it is entirely profligate in its responsibilities to Australia's budget. Again in question time today the Treasurer put out a few warning signals. He has been talking about problems in the economy, about the fact that the housing market has settled down somewhat and about there being a few problems with debts. The greatest problem that the Australian people faced in this election was that they were up against a government that would spend anything, do anything and say anything to get re-elected. The government did not care what it promised to whom and how much it would cost, as long as it got back into power. However worthy these propositions are-and some of them, I would argue, are worthy-the context is that it was about the coalition buying its way back into government at any cost. Properly answered, the great concern that people had about interest rates would have seen this lot thrown off the Treasury bench and back into the oblivion that they deserve. Quite simply, they were utterly irresponsible in their spending this year. From one end of the country to the other-unless they are Liberal Party apparatchik, a member of the government front-bench or one of those people elected on the back of what the Prime Minister and others promised-no-one could argue that there is a shred of responsibility in what it has done. The general context, properly put by commentators Australia wide, identifies that what this government needs to do over the triennium until the next election is to bring the budget back into order. But one of the first pieces of government business is to lay before us a series of issues that have particular point: we have promises of half a billion dollars, $1 billion and $2 billion. I would argue that some are particularly worthy. We are not going to gainsay the fact that this will provide a benefit to ordinary Australian pensioners. It will also provide a benefit directly to self-funded retirees. In both those cases, the benefit is worthy. But it is also necessary because it is this very government that those two groups of people need to be defended against. Why is that so? Why has a government that has been profligate in its spending chosen to target these measures in order to help people. Why is it necessary? Why is that the case? It is because the cost of living for ple on a pension or benefit is not the same as the cost of living for everyone else in the community. The general low-inflation period that we have-courtesy of the HawkeKeating governments and of the major changes that were made through the middle of the 1980s and 1990s-has provided the basis for 14 years' worth of growth. It has also had an impact on self-funded retirees. Retirees who enjoy a higher level of income during a period of high interest rates have less money to survive on during a period of low inflation and low interest rates, particularly those people who provided for themselves. They definitely got a benefit from the Commonwealth, but they made a greater input into their future benefit by going without at the time and there is a case that they should in fact receive some extra recompense. I would agree with that. I spent a long time during the period of the Hawke and Keating governments attempting to convince the then Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Social Security, Brian Howe, that there was a case to answer with regard to self-funded retirees. I argued that those people who had worked hard all of their lives faced the same cost pressures that people on pensions faced, except that people on pensions had the health care concession cardparticularly at that stage, when the pension rate was $6,500 or $7,000 a year and self-funded retirees who had worked in the education sector, for instance, were on $11,500 or $12,000 a year. That concession card gave them access to a series of state benefits for travel and other things, which meant that their relative cost of living was lower than for those who were on that benefit. I have to confess that I did not succeed with Mr Howe, but I did succeed finally when Graham Richardson came in, because Graham understood two things: he not only peounderstood the merit of the case but he understood the politics of the case as well-that those people who had done it hard and were effectively in straitened circumstances deserved a go-and he made the decision to extend that health care card and those fringe benefits to that small group of people. I am proud of the fact that, working in the Treasurer's electorate office at the time, I pushed that case and I succeeded from that office in bringing that change into place under a Labor government. There are many people that have benefited from it. In this bill the government seeks to extend that benefit by allowing those self-funded retirees an extra concession to get access to some of the things that have been there for pensioners. For the utility concession the bill provides for a utility supplement for senior Australians of aged pension or veteran pension age who currently receive income support. Furthermore, there is a new seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees who hold a Commonwealth seniors health card. In the first instance, I played a key part in getting them that concession to start off with, and here we have an expansion of people's capacity to receive what pensioners can access but that those self-funded retirees cannot. In a low-inflation period, the PBS costs have been reduced, but they still face problems with travel and with paying the electricity, gas and other myriad bills and cost pressures that come upon them. So I think this is actually a good measure. There is a problem of the ongoing cost to the Commonwealth of providing these benefits. Whatever the budget figures say now about the cost of these measures being $200 million, $600 million or whatever, the context, of course, is that this inevitably will be small bickies compared to what it is going to be when a quarter of the population is aged-when the boomers, I being one of them, will represent one-quarter of the community. So whatever cost indicators there are will increase almost exponentially. Therefore, supportability and sustainability of these measures is a key ingredient. There is health-care concession for people on pensions and, set beside that because they are on income support, the state governments have for a long time provided a series of measures to assist those people. So the second area where the government have attempted to balance this up is through a specific utility supplement for people on aged pensions so that they will get some assistance with the key things that really hit them now-gas, electricity and so on. That is a good measure as well, but you have to place that into a broader context. They need the assistance because people on pensions and other income supplements are at the end of the scale where the relative amounts of money they spend on utilities and on the everyday necessities of life are proportionately far greater than for people on much higher incomes. The proportionality is significant and it is important. In my electorate of Blaxland, there are a lot of people on income support as aged pensioners, and they have told me time and again just how hard it is to get by since the GST came into effect. Indeed, one of my branch members, Peter Morton from Chester Hill branch, has told me a number of times that his ability to provide for himself-and other people's ability to provide for themselves-is very much hit not just by the GST but by the fact that a government entity that this government now half owns is belting the daylights out of them to the tune of a dollar a day. That government entity, Telstra, which is relatively trammelled because the government still owns half, has increased its line charges to $28 a month. That is a dollar a day for every pensioner in Australia with a phone, which is an absolute necessity for them. Peter says that getting the rental supplement and utilities assistance will be a good thing for him but it is going to be swallowed up anyway-he will be a little bit better off with that but his bigger problem is some assistance with the Telstra bill, and he has properly identified that the government is entirely responsible here. Companies can get a tax deduction on their costs but, of course, individuals cannot. He said that on gas bills-he has told me about this a number of times and it is true-under the heading ‘gas supply' the state government provides a quarterly $16 credit on the bill and this has gone up along with the rental fees. He also makes a point about the one dollar a day for Telstra charges. Where is the utility supplement in relation to Telstra charges? It is not there. Line rental fees are compounded by the GST, so you have not only got the one dollar a day, there is an extra 10c on top that is going directly into federal government coffers. Of course, they argue that they are only collecting it for the states. Mr Deputy Speaker Beazley, as you know, this is a Commonwealth government tax, just like all other Commonwealth government taxes, imposed on people so they pay a double whammy, because 51 cents of that dollar go directly to the Commonwealth government. With respect to increases in charges for utilities, affecting aged pensioners Australia wide, the government says in this bill, ‘We'll help you pay the gas and we'll help you pay the electricity'-they are private entities or part state-owned entities-‘and we'll pocket the full amount of money that we can in Telstra line charges and we'll charge you the GST on top of it.' I think Peter is right: this is fee outrageous. They actually need another supplement to the bill to fix it up. There is a $100-a-year utility supplement. Peter Morton says that that would be welcomed, but it does not even cover the cost of the Telstra line rentals, let alone the electricity or gas. should be research done or an inquiry carried out on the impact of these hidden costs. But the government of course would rather that these costs were kept hidden. They do not really want to deal with the fundamental constraints on people on income support. Peter also asked how the utility providers justify those costs and why it costs Telstra $1 a day to keep a phone line connected. I think I can tell him that it does not cost Telstra $1 a day to keep a phone line connected. This is a $1 tax on every Australian pensioner and every person using a phone Australia wide. When the member for Melbourne was the shadow minister, we in the opposition rightly argued that these exorbitant increases in charges were reprehensible to the nth degree. There is no margin for people on fixed incomes to handle a big increase-unless it drops, as almost manna from heaven, from this government from time to time just before an election. There is $66 billion in funding this year. What does the government spend in the off-years? If you go back a year or so, you find it is about $4 billion. There a big difference proportionally. But we all know it is about the member for Bennelong and his cohorts buying an election. Peter Morton and all of my constituentsthe people who do it tough at the end of the line where you are dependent on some government largesse and these extra little bits to make your life more liveable-deserve to have a utility supplement that covers not only what the government are promising in this bill but also the real costs imposed in relation to Telstra. So, while I welcome the general provisions of this bill, I understandas everyone else in the opposition does-that this is a way for the government to buy favour. There are significant questions about the sustainability of these provisions into the future and there are significant problems that will arise due to their picking and choosing There which grandparents will get help and which grandparents will not. So we will support the provisions but we make the argument that this is about buying your way into office and it is ultimately unsustainable.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: Rankin) (5.55 p.m.)Labor supports this legislation on the basis that it will go some way towards easing the financial pressure on pensioners and self-funded retirees. However, I want to take this opportunity to express concerns, which have already been expressed by the member for Blaxland, about the sustainability of the government's spending program. I will go through a number of the provisions of the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004. The utility supplement is welcomed. It is not a lot of money. It is $100 a year for singles and $50 for each member of a couple. It is designed to assist our senior Australians to pay their regular household bills from the utilities whose services they use. The self-funded retiree payment is a new is seniors' concession that allows $200 per annum for self-funded retirees who are eligible for a Commonwealth seniors health card. We of course support that provision. There is a change to the carer's payment. This is by way of increasing the number of hours that carers may spend in work, training or study without losing their qualification for a carer payment. We certainly support that. The maximum length of time that a carer may temporarily cease providing care in order to take training, education and voluntary or paid work and still retain their qualification for the carer payment is currently 20 hours per week. Under this legislation, that will be increased to 25 hours per week. In addition, there are new benefits relating to child care. Grandparents who have primary care of a grandchild or grandchildren and who are receiving income support will be entitled to a special rate of child-care benefit. That will cover the full cost of care fees charged to eligible grandparents by approved child-care services. We have some genuine concerns with this provision, and that is why the member for Sydney has moved a second reading amendment. The amendment criticises the government for not adequately supporting grandparent carers. In particular, under this legislation there is no support for grandparents who cannot find a place for grandchildren in approved care and who are thus forced to use registered care. They are given no special assistance to meet the cost of registered care. We are bewildered as to why that distinction would be made. It means that a large number of grandparents who are carers miss out on this particular benefit. There are desirable changes in relation to veterans' entitlements. The bill extends bereavement payments to widows of TPI veterans and ex-servicemen. Of course, we greatly appreciate the contribution of ex-servicemen, who have made big sacrifices to keep our country free. We think this is also a reasonable measure. The cumulative impact of these measures is $972 million over four years. That is an affordable set of initiatives. But it is an cation of funding that is on top of a very large additional spending program from this government. In fact, it is a massive spending program. If we count the budget initiatives and all of the initiatives that have been taken since the May budget-that is, right up to and including the election campaign-the total amount of extra spending over four years is a staggering $61 billion. Not only is that a huge amount of money, but I have been able to make an assessment of how much of that $61 billion is consumption spending and how much is investment spending. Disturbingly, the answer is that only $5 billion of that $61 billion is, in fact, child- investment spending-and here I am being rather generous, because that includes Customs posts in Beijing and Jakarta. Of course that will do some good, but the direct economic stimulus from those Customs posts will be felt in Beijing and Jakarta, and not in Australia. I know it is a small point, but I thought it was worth making. The big point and the big story here is that, in order to be re-elected, this government has over the last few months committed Australian taxpayers to $61 billion of extra spending, of which only $5 billion is investment spending. The problem we have in this country is that there is a spending spree, a consumption binge, which can have only dire consequences for the Australian economy. Since this government came to office in 1996, it has deliberately addicted Australians to debt. We are now in a situation where households have negative savings-they are dissaving-and they are continuing on a consumption binge. Yet they are struggling to make ends meet in that, instead of saving for this consumption, they are more and more putting it on the credit card and taking out larger and larger mortgages. The total impact is that just as Australians are strugallogling to make ends meet so is Australia. That has shown up in a current account deficit of 6.5 per cent of gross domestic product. Mr Deputy Speaker Hatton, that is a current account deficit of a similar order of magnitude to, or even larger than, the current account deficit of the mid-1980s which prompted your predecessor, Mr Keating, to warn of the prospect of Australia becoming a banana republic. The Hawke and Keating governments put in place a comprehensive reform program designed to ensure that we are never again in that situation. It was a problem which the Hawke and Keating governments inherited and understood, and they responded by putting in place that comprehensive reform program. As a result of that program, we should have been able to look forward and say, ‘We will never be so vulnerable again'-and yet we are. We are very vulnerable to any external shocks and to an economic slowdown because this government has addicted Australians to debt. That debt is showing up in our foreign debt. When the government said they would cut foreign debt-when it rolled out the debt truck, and when the debt truck was circling around Australia-the Prime Minister, then opposition leader, said he would follow policies which would over time reduce foreign debt. Instead of reducing foreign debt, they have more than doubled foreign debt. Using the Treasurer's favoured measure of the debt per person in Australia which he used when he was shadow Treasurer-our foreign debt is now $20,000 per man, woman and child in this country. It was in the order of $10,000 per man, woman and child in this country when the then opposition leader, and now Prime Minister, promised that an incoming Howard government would follow policies which would bring down the foreign debt. Instead the government has doubled foreign debt, and it has addicted the Australian people to debt. The short-term economic consequences are already starting to appear. Figures released just today and yesterday are already showing evidence of a substantial economic slowdown as people realise how vulnerable they are, how overburdened with debt they are. House prices have started to fall. There is evidence that retail sales are now starting to fall and that there is an economic slowdown. This is an economic slowdown I talked about in my address-in-reply speech just three or four days ago. I did not realise that within three or four days evidence would already be coming in pointing to the high likelihood of such an economic slowdown. We can only hope that it will be a soft landing and not a hard landing. We can only hope that consumers will realise how overextended they are and gradually withdraw their consumption spending so that we land softly. If they do not, and if they were to continue consuming at the sorts of rates at which they have been consuming, then ultimately the inflationary consequences of that would mean that the Reserve Bank would have to intervene. So let us hope it is a soft landing, and not a hard landing as a result of Reserve Bank intervention, as inflation moves out of the target range of the Reserve Bank. That is the short-term economic problem confronting Australia, but what of the long term economic problem? Mr Deputy Speaker, as member for Blaxland, you also alluded to the problems of the ageing of the population and the sustainability of the sorts of measures that were announced here today. We know that the $900 million associated with these measures will not, of itself, break the bank, but this government is going to have to start thinking seriously about investing in the nation's future instead of continuing to promote a consumption boom. The government has committed $61 billion of new spending over the four years from the May budget, and all but $5 billion of it is consumption spending. The measures in this legislation are directly targeted at an ageing population; they are targeted at pensioners and self-funded retirees. But I have to ask the question that is opened up by this debate: who is going to pay for the ageing population in the generations to come? The truth of the matter is that fewer and fewer babies are being born in Australia as the fertility rate collapses. In 1961, at the peak of the baby boom, Australian couples had almost four children, on average, and now it is down to less than two-1.7 children, to be precise. The Intergenerational Report, which the Treasury produced two years ago-as confirmed by a Productivity Commission report on the ageing of the population which was released just last week-forecasts that the figure of 1.7 children will continue to fall around 1.65 children. The fertility rate will continue to fall, and that means fewer and fewer children will be born. But those four babies per family who were born at the peak of the baby boom are ageing. They are now already in their 40s and 50s and over the projection period of the ergenerational Report-the next 40 yearsthose same baby boomers will be flooding into our hospitals and into our nursing homes. That is why the Treasurer has finally realised there is a problem with health spending in Australia. Marvellous technologies will keep those Australians alive longer. And that is what we want; that is a reflection of the progress we have made and of the improvement in living standards in this country. We want people to be able to stay alive longer and to be healthier. But declining mortality rates combined with collapsing fertility rates mean that there will be such ageing of the population that there will be four million extra Australians over the age of 65 four decades from now. How many more young people will there be? The answer is a very worrying one. There will be fewer young people. There will not be more people under the age of 15; there will be fewer people under the age of 15 four decades from now than there are in Australia today. We will have indeed around 250,000-we cannot be precise about these things-fewer children in 40 years time. What does that all mean for health care costs? The Productivity Commission estimates that health and aged care costs will take $13 of every $100 earned in Australia that is government spending on health and aged care costs. That will be almost a doubling of present costs. Should we be panicked about the ageing of the population? No, it is not a crisis but it certainly is a challenge. Sadly, the government only realised two years ago, after the to preparation-I doubt that the government commissioned it-of the Intergenerational Report by the Treasury, that the ageing of the population was a problem. The problem, or challenge, is best solved by reference to the three Ps: population, participation and productivity. With the first, population, the die is Int- already cast-as I have already explained. The ageing of the population over the next 40 years is a consequence of decisions taken by parents over the last 40 years. So the ageing of the population is inevitable. There is nothing that we can do about the ageing of the population. I will even invoke the phrase used by the Treasurer. He said, ‘Demography is destiny'. He is right about that. Occasionally he gets something right and on this occasion he is right. The die is cast. The ageing of the population is a reality and we are not going to be able to prevent it. So how can we meet the challenge of the an ageing of the population? We do it through the other two Ps. The second P is participation. Some good things can be done here. An increasingly skilled female work force will come into existence over the 40-year time frame covered by the Intergenerational Report and the Productivity Commission report. As those highly skilled women come into the work force in increasing numbersand as they come to represent the norm rather than the exception, as perhaps was the case 40 years ago when educational outcomes were not quite as good as they are now-that will increase participation by working age women in the work force. That is a good thing. We should be encouraging that by encouraging family friendly provisions in and beyond the industrial relations system. Labor is the only party that is prepared to use the industrial relations system to encourage the provision of family friendly arrangements in agreements. So we can improve participation, and it will happen for working age women. But the Treasurer has put almost all his eggs in one basket: improving the participation of older Australians. This is the work till you drop scheme. The Productivity Commission report that was released this week is a fascinating read on this matter. It is an indictment on the Treasurer. The Productivity Commission in fact did various sensitivity analyses in terms of changing the participation rate of older Australians. It came to the conclusion that changing the participation rate of older Australians in the work force can have at best negligible impacts on income growth in this country. So the very basket in which the Treasurer has put almost all his eggs is a dud basket. We cannot get there simply by requiring older Australians to work till they drop. That second P, participation of older Australians, will make very little difference. It will do very little in terms of responding effectively to the challenge of the ageing of the population. So that leaves us with the third P. The third P is productivity growth. That is the key. As Labor has long recognised, today's productivity growth is tomorrow's prosperity. That is why Labor put in place that comprehensive and coherent economic reform program of the 1980s and early 1990s. It was designed to lift productivity growth by creating the open competitive economy. And Labor achieved that. The results have been astonishing. Australian productivity growth since around 1993 has outpaced that of just about every country in the world except Finland and Ireland. It certainly has outstripped that of the United States. But, having opened the door and created the open competitive economy, we cannot open that same door again. Therefore, it is incumbent on this generation of Australians, who are benefiting from the prosperity gained from the yield of the economic reforms of the 1980s and early 1990s, to identify and invest in the new sources of productivity growth in this country. And we know what they are; it is not a secret. The new sources of productivity growth in Australia are investment in skills, investment in new ideas and investment in infrastructure. On all three grounds the government fails miserably. The Productivity Commission and the OECD have both concluded that in the 1990s skills formation actually detracted from productivity growth in Australia. We have underinvested in skills. We have certainly underinvested in new ideas: business spending on research and development as a share of gross domestic product has been falling since the change of government. It has picked up a bit just in the last couple of years but the gap between Australia and the OECD continues to widen. And we are underinvesting in infrastructure. When the Governor General outlined the forward program for this government, there was no coherent economic reform program designed to secure ongoing productivity growth in this country to combat the ageing of the population. While I welcome this legislation, the fact is that the government has failed appallingly to recognise the problem and to meet the challenges of Australia's ageing population.

Speaker: Ms LEY
Title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY
text: During the 2004 election campaign, this government pledged extra assistance to certain important groups in the Australian community. This extra assistance is aimed at self-funded retirees, older Australians, carers on income support, grandparents caring for children and certain disability pensioners. The Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004 gives effect to the government's commitments. Firstly, all holders of the Commonwealth seniors health card will benefit from a new payment of $200 a year-the seniors concession allowance. The new payment recognises the fact that most self-funded retirees do not receive concessions for energy rates, water and sewerage, and motor vehicle registration from state and territory governments. It also acknowledges the community contribution made by this group of people in providing for their own retirement. The payment will be split into two payments-one in December and one in June each year-to people who are eligible cardholders on 1 December and 1 June respectively. It will be indexed twice yearly, will be exempt from income tax and will remain payable during temporary absences from Australia of up to 13 weeks. In a further measure, the bill provides for senior Australians of age pension age or veteran pension age on income support to attract a new payment known as the utilities allowance. The payment will help these people to pay regular household bills such as gas and electricity. The new payment will generally be $100 a year for singles and $50 a year for each member of a couple. It will be paid twice each year following the pension indexation adjustments on 20 March and 20 September. Again, it will be indexed twice yearly, will not attract income tax and will still be paid if the person is temporarily absent from Australia for up to 13 weeks. These two significant new payments will help ease the financial demands on over two million older members of our community. This bill will establish additional support for an important group of people in our community-those providing care for an adult or a child with a disability. These carers will now be able to spend 25 rather than 20 hours a week in work, training or study without losing qualification for carer payment. This greater flexibility will improve carers' work force opportunities and allow more of a break from caring without affecting their carer payment eligibility. Grandparents with the primary care of their grandchildren fall into a further group who will benefit from the extra assistance provided by this bill. This particular measure is in addition to the waiver of the work, training and study test for child-care benefit already implemented by the government which allows eligible grandparents access to child-care benefit for up to 50 hours of approved child care a week. This bill will now make child care more affordable for grandparent carers on income support, such as age pension or carer payment, by enabling them to have access to a special rate of child-care benefit. This special rate will cover the full cost of child-care fees charged to eligible grandparents by approved child-care services. Finally, the bill will provide for increased bereavement payments under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 in respect of disability pensioners who are receiving above the general rate of disability pension. Previously, the bereavement payment had been limited to 100 per cent of the general rate. I thank all those on our side and on the other side who contributed to the debate today, and I again commend the bill to the House. Question put: That the words proposed to be omitted (Ms Plibersek's amendment) stand part of the question. The House divided. Speaker: Ms LEY
Title: NOES
text: by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA (100% MEDICARE REBATE AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2004 Second Reading Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Mr Abbott: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: At the outset I had better clarify some pervasive confusion about the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004. It is not like me to correct the clerks, because they are always correcting me, but it is not a 1,000 per cent Medicare rebate-as the clerk just read; it is 100 per cent. A 1,000 per cent Medicare rebate would be a lot more expensive than $1.7 billion, and I am not sure that the Howard government would stump up for that times 10. If the clerk is a little anxious about having misread the bill title, he should feel in good company because the Minister for Health and Ageing, when he spoke in the second reading debate on the last sitting Thursday, consistently referred to the bill as ‘the 90 cent Medicare rebate bill'. It is very clearly audible on the tape; I would recommend it as required viewing to anybody in this parliament who is interested in Medicare issues. Of course, by the time we had the Hansard, it was corrected so the right figure-100 per cent-was written, but it does give you the occasional moment of concern that the minister for health seems to so fundamentally misunderstand the basis of a $1.7 billion measure that he is putting before the parliament. In truth the measure is for a 100 per cent Medicare rebate for unreferred GP services. As members who were in this parliament prior to the last election might recall-and I am sure those who were contesting seats for election into this parliament would also recall-the health debate last term was about the Howard government's neglect of our health system. We saw bulk-billing rates plummet under the Howard government, we saw out-of-pocket costs to see the doctor soar and we saw that result in a national figure of six million fewer consultations in the Australian community with GPs. That is six million times Australians looked in their purses or wallets and decided they could not afford to see a GP under the policies of the Howard government. We on this side of the House feared that many of the times that people postponed getting medical care from their GP they were putting off preventative health checks-the sort of thing they think they will get done the next month or the month after when they have a bit more money but, because of the financial barrier, they end up never getting done-or they were turning up looking for free care in emergency departments of public hospitals, putting them under more stress and strain.
