They take this as effectively a supplement that should have been provided earlier and a supplement that does not really cover the demands that they have made. If you take this further, in terms of what we have heard this week and in past weeks from the Treasurer, from the Minister for Health and Ageing, and from others about the Intergenerational Report and problems associated with the fact that the community is ageing, the graph works its way up very exponentially. Not now, but in the next decade, and the decade after that. Mr Georgiou-Medicare Gold!

Speaker: Mr HATTON
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Poor simple souls; they just want to interject and have a go at what Labor has put forward as a policy that rationalises health costs in the private area. Be that as it may, we have a critical problem here. For my sins, I am a 1951 baby boomer. Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, like you and others, I am part of the baby boomer generation. We will be in the simple situation where the number of aged people in the population will double from 12½ per cent to 25 per cent of the population. Mr Lloyd interjecting

Speaker: Mr HATTON
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: The Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads may be younger than that. Be that as it may, whether he is a baby boomer or not, whether he is joining me or not, those of my generation and I take full responsibility for the fact that our share of the total community will increase, the health care costs of the total community will increase, reliance upon Medicare will increase and people on reduced incomes-because incomes will always be less than the baby boomers will want-will also face the situation where they will make a determination about going to the doctor: is the 100 per cent rebate enough or will their cost inexorably increase? I do not think this is going to do the job. I think it is patchwork. I can understand why it has been put together: the government has done whatever it took to get re-elected. I can understand that, in order to get back into office, it spent in the order of $21 billion in May 2001 plus what it spent in the election. I can understand that, despite the fact that we have low inflation, in just three years the government spent triple what they spent in 2001 of the constituents' money-the money of the people of Australia-in order to get back. I can understand that that worked. But the short-term improvement of the government's position is to the long-term detriment of the Australian people. It depends how you take it. On budget day there was the $66 billion or the $61 billion of expenditure, variously categorised as $37 billion or $50 billion, and in one single day of the election campaign there was the $6 billion worth of promises. It is staggering stuff. The drunken sailor stuff really resonates regarding the amount the government promised in order to snatch back office. It was very successful. It got an increase of 1.8 per cent in its national vote. It got an increase in the number of members in this place. But the price to be paid will be paid by the people of Australia. Across a whole series of portfolios, across a whole series of programs, it will be taken out of the hide of the Australian people. This is the government's vainglorious attempt to match Labor. It is their attempt to say, ‘Labor is not really the party of Medicare'-despite the fact that Labor started Medibank; despite the fact that the Fraser government year after year, over seven full years, gutted Medibank and sought to stab it in the stomach, as the Prime Minister wished to do with Medicare. The coalition, in that wonderful inversion which is so much a part of their approach to things, are now the great defenders of the status quo; they are now the great defenders supposedly of Medicare. Unfortunately, I have to tell Australia's doctors and the people of Australia who line up either in Blaxland, Lowe, Kooyong or Indi that this is not the full story. This little package is about covering the coalition's derriere in regard to health policy. It is about dealing with an antagonistic interest group, the Australian Medical Association, and attempting to assuage not only their fears but also their demand for an increase effectively in their wages. It will only go part way to solving the government's problem; it is not a full attempt at all to deal with the underlying realities in terms either of the doctors or of service provision for the whole of Australia. The fundamental provision in this legislation is the 100 per cent Medicare rebate. One hundred per cent sounds good, unless you are a GP practising in Australia and arguing that it is not enough. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mrs HULL
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: To come into this House to speak on legislation like this bill is a great opportunity. Many times when you come into the House to speak on legislation you might not have great news and great history to help put forward a very convincing debate, but health is one area that this government has excelled in. I am very proud to walk into this House many times and espouse the virtues of this government and its provision of additional health services. Let me set the scene. I do not want to be accused of not being relevant by the member for Blaxland, so I want to start off by setting the scene by providing the history of benefits that this government has provided over the past eight years. These benefits have worked to correct and improve Australia's health system and to maintain our world-class services. It might not be recognised on the opposite side of the House that we do have world-class health services, but I absolutely confirm for the member for Blaxland that we have world-class health services, believe you me, and this government has played a very big part in ensuring that we continue to have world-class services and that we continue to have them in rural and regional Australia. We have worked to increase the number of doctors training and practising outside metropolitan areas. We have established rural clinical schools, one of which I am very proud to host in my electorate of Riverina: the University of New South Wales School of Rural Health. It has gone a long way to ensuring that those young students who are doing their degree will look to return to and regional practice in establishing their craft of medicine. We have made private health insurance more affordable and accessible, thereby reducing the strain on the public health system. We have introduced the successful after-hours clinic program; it has been very successful in my electorate of Riverina. It has established clinics throughout Australia including, as I have said, in the Riverina, with the Riverina Division of General Practice as an excellent example of a successful after-hours medical clinic. This after-hours clinic operates from rooms in Calvary Hospital. The clinic provides valuable and much needed medical services to people throughout Wagga Wagga and the surrounding area. It is serviced by a majority of local doctors, who work on a roster system to ensure that this clinic is staffed after hours during the week and on weekends and public holidays, thus reducing the load on the terribly stressed state hospital system. What we have is an ineffective New South Wales Labor government which has stressed the hospital system to the maximum, and this Howard-Anderson federal coalition government has put in place with the various ministers an opportunity for people to be able to action other health services beyond those public health services that we see so often espoused by the opposite side of the room. We have achieved many great things in the area of health. We are committed to continuing those improvements to our health system and ensuring access for all Australians. Since I was elected as the member for Riverina in 1998 more than $36 million in federal government funding has been delivered into my region in the area of health alone. This funding has gone into many different areas of health, including $1.2 million to establish a rural obstetrics training network in the Riverina and Murray region. That is something that we need to be critirural cally concerned with. We were faced with the prospect of mums having to be flown to Sydney for perfectly normal deliveries, and we were faced with the shutdown of all private obstetric services. But this government under the Minister for Health and Ageing, Tony Abbott, combined with myself of course-I had a bit of an input into thisdetermined that we would establish a rural obstetrics training network. Now we are up and running, contracts are signed, and we have some very good people on the job, including Dr Ian Stewart, a gynaecologist and obstetrician who, for a number of years now, has been operating in this area and understands how we are going to provide obstetric services in rural and regional areas into the future. This project is a fantastic pilot. It be picked up and put anywhere in Australia to ensure services will be maintained for rural women who want to have their children in their communities. We also have $820,000 for supplying specialist medical services to towns in the Riverina and we had $13.7 million to set up a rural clinical school at Wagga Wagga to address the shortage of medical practitioners, and it has just been funded again for the next four years. In my electorate of Riverina one of the greatest concerns in health is access to a doctor, not access to bulk-billing. The communities throughout my region and beyond struggle to attract doctors, particularly ones who are willing to establish a permanent practice. One small community in my electorate had 22 locums in 18 months. Their issue certainly was not: ‘Am I going to be bulkbilled?' Their issue was: ‘Am I going to have a doctor?' We have resolved that issue for them. This government has provided a secure service in most of the towns throughout my electorate. Some of the initiatives that I have announced in the past have been significant in the way in which we have looked at health in a different capacity since this government put in place the health measures that were going to address many of the shortfalls that came about through 13 years of Labor rule. The Nationals have worked in coalition with the health minister to increase the number of general practitioners in rural and regional Australia and to encourage students to explore the options of practising outside the cities. I recall when John Anderson and former Minister Michael Wooldridge went out and had a look at the way in which services were declining in rural and regional Australia, had a look at the significant issues that confronted rural residents when they were seeking health services and then decided on a plan that would take us forward. We need to can be eternally grateful to those two members of parliament for looking outside the square and determining that they could in fact put in place many great initiatives that would see these things resolved. They do not get resolved overnight, they take some years, but it is a beginning. The journey of a thousand steps begins with just one, and this government took the first step. We are very proud of that. As a result of these policies over 25 per cent of Australia's medical students now come from rural areas. That is something we did not have when the coalition came into government. We did not have a quota of students who were able to come from rural areas to study medicine. Medicine needed a 99.9 per cent TER or UAI, and rural students were not able to feature very highly in that area. Now they can have 85 per cent and we can do an assessment and deliver rural students into medical courses before delivering them right back to rural Australia where they came from. That was an initiative that came from this coalition government. Doctors are much more likely to return to practise in rural and regional Australia if they have come from the bowels of our areas. The Rural Australian Medical Undergraduate Scholarship Scheme provides $10,000 each year to undergraduate medical students from rural and regional backgrounds. There were only 100 medical students from rural areas in 1996 when this government came into power. Now we have 500 medical students receiving those RMS scholarships alone. That is a very significant input by any government. In addition, the Medical Rural Bonded Scholarship Scheme provides over $20,000 a year to students during their medical degree. In return, these students agree to work for six years in a rural or remote area. I think that is very credible and laudable. It is a great program that gives students an opportunity, and these places are on top of general places. It is not conscription. These kids are signing up. They know what they are doing, and they want to have the opportunity to work in rural and regional Australia. These two schemes alone build on our other policies that will increase the number of these doctors. These policies include specialist retention payments, extra funding to support rural GPs who perform minor operations and obstetrics, and attracting more overseas trained doctors to areas where there is a shortage of doctors and communities are unable to get an Australian trained doctor. As I said, training doctors does not happen overnight. It is a process that takes many years. But we will continue to build on these existing policies, and we will continue to attract general practitioners into rural medicine. So all of these initiatives have delivered benefits-but then we come in and say, as Tim Shaw did, ‘Wait, there's more.' The decision by this government to raise the Medicare benefit from 85 per cent to 100 per cent of the schedule fee has been welcomed in my electorate because it means an increase of $4.60 in the Medicare rebate for a standard surgery consultation. This increase in the rebate applies to consultations in doctors' surgeries, after hours, at home and in aged care facility visits. It is a tremendous initiative that the minister has put to the House. I listened to the member for Blaxland and I really did not much like the Labor Party's alternative to our Medicare rebate policy, which was to offer 100 per cent of the schedule fee of bulk-billed consultations only. If you are in an area where, as the member for Blaxland has just indicated, he has approximately 95 per cent of doctors bulk-billing, that is great. We have Labor areas propped up with mass city areas that can get bulk-billing at 95 per cent. In my electorate of Riverina, and many other rural areas right across Australia, bulkbilling has traditionally been non-existent. We would not have received any benefit out of the Labor policy at all. I ask the Labor Party: how would this have benefited people in the electorate of Riverina where general practitioners simply do not bulk-bill? I find it hard to comprehend why the opposition would seek to create a policy that neglected to consider the consequences for those who are unable to access bulk-billing. The situation is better now than it was when the opposition were in power for 13 years. We have traditionally had no bulk-billing in my electorate. We all want to have an opportunity to spread some good health news. In order to give my colleagues an opportunity to be able to spread their good message, their good humoured news, I suggest that we all accept that this is an exciting initiative. It is part of a suite of the many exciting initiatives that have been administered in this House by this coalition government.

Speaker: Mr GEORGIOU
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I wish to support the comments of the honourable member for Riverina on the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004. Medicare has been one of the cornerstones of the Australian public health system since it was introduced by Gough Whitlam almost 30 years ago. I take the honourable member for Blaxland's point: I do not think there is much point in beating around the bush and pretending that the coalition has always been unequivocally committed to Medibank or to Medicare as it now is. That is not the case. Many of us recollect the constant changes made to Medibank under the Fraser government-indeed some of us participated in them. There were our successive promises in the 13 years of opposition to fundamentally change the basic components of Medicare once it was reinstalled by the Hawke government. The fact is, however, that, whatever the Labor Party says, this all changed with the demise of Fightback and when John Howard as Leader of the Opposition gave an unequivocal commitment that the coalition would fully retain the Medicare system. I believe this commitment has been honoured and indeed exceeded. One of the Howard government's great success stories has been its reinforcement of Medicare. It may have taken some ideological revolutions to get there, but once the commitment was made it was kept. The government has worked to secure the long-term viability of Medicare to ensure that all Australians have improved access to the multitude of medical services available to the community and to keep our medical system affordable for those who need to access it. The Strengthening Medicare policy was an important step towards meeting these objectives. It is worth reflecting on some of its key components. Some 60 per cent of GP consultations in Australia involve medical services delivered to children under the age of 16 years and to concession card holderspension, health care and Commonwealth seniors card holders. The government determined that when a bulk-billing GP treated these patients the payment to the doctor would be increased by $5, and further increased to $7.50 if the doctor were located in remote or rural areas which included all of Tasmania. These amounts have increased to $5.10 and $7.65 respectively as a result of indexation from 1 November of this year. Before we turn our attention to the next step in this process-the 100 per cent Medicare policy that is the subject of this bill-it is worthwhile noting the success of the earlier bulk-billing initiative. The national bulkbilling rate at the end of the September 2004 quarter was 71.8 per cent. Since the Strengthening Medicare package was announced earlier this year it has risen by 5.3 percentage points, or eight per cent in relative terms. The national bulk-billing rate for Australians aged 65 years or older is even higher, with 82.1 per cent of all medical consultations in that category now being bulkbilled. In sum, in all states and territories the rate of bulk-billing continues to increase even before the introduction of 100 per cent Medicare in January 2005. The 100 per cent Medicare will deliver additional benefits to GPs. It will make medical consultations even more affordable for patients. In our health system, medical benefits are based on a fee determined for each medical service, which is the ‘schedule fee'. Until now the medical benefit paid for a GP consultation has been set at 85 per cent of the schedule fee. That percentage applies to all out-of-hospital medical benefits. From 1 January 2005 the MBS will pay a 100 per cent rebate for schedule fees for all GP visits in lieu of the 85 per cent figure that applied historically. In dollar terms this change means an additional payment of $2.10 for a short consultation, $4.60 for a normal consultation and up to $12.90 for extended consultations in excess of 40 minutes in duration. For a standard 15-minute consultation in a GP's surgery, the new Medicare rebate will be $30.85. Importantly, this very substantial increase in payments for a GP consultation will apply to all consultations. It does not matter whether or not the doctor bulk-bills the patient for a medical consultation. That is a very important point of distinction, both philosophically and in policy terms, between the government and Labor. The Labor alternative announced during the election campaign was to increase the rebate for GP consultations 100 per cent of the schedule fee, but only in circumstances where the consultation was bulk-billed. The government is committed to the independence of the doctor-patient relationship. Under this policy the choice of whether or not to bulk-bill would remain with the doctor. The increase in the rebate to 100 per cent of the schedule fee will apply to all medical consultations regardless of whether or not the doctor elects to bulk-bill the patient. If the doctor does bulk-bill, the doctor will ceive the additional payment of $4.60. If the consultation is not bulk-billed, the patient will derive the benefit of the additional money to reduce the out-of-pocket costs. This is a policy position that allows doctors and patients to concentrate on the essential task of providing and receiving quality health care, knowing that minimal costs will be incurred by the patient. The higher rebate for medical consultations will apply to consultations delivered in a doctor's surgery, the patient's home or in a residential aged care facility, and even to hospital tions involving non-admitted patients. It should be noted-and this is important-that this decision to increase the rebate to 100 per cent of the schedule fee in no way impacts on or detracts from other bulkbilling initiatives and incentives that I lined earlier. The Howard government's $5 and $7.50 bulk-billing incentives, introduced as part of the Strengthening Medicare package, will continue to be paid over and above the base schedule fees. In a similar vein, titlements under the Practice Incentives Program will not be impacted on by the 100 per cent Medicare initiative. As was pointed out, the 100 per cent Medicare initiative will cost $1.8 billion over four years. This is a commitment that can be made and a benefit that can be passed on to all Australians because this government has delivered such strong to economic growth and prosperity over a substantial period. It is a policy that will ensure that Australians have better access to medical services and that those services are more affordable. There are a number of other initiatives involved in the government's commitment to Strengthening Medicare, including Round the Clock Medicare, which funds a diversity of after-hours medical centres. One of the key elements of Round the Clock Medicare is its flexibility and its capacity to respond to redifferent circumstances and environments. Labor's alternative, Medicare After Hours, relies on just one model-GP clinics colocated with public hospitals. This is a onesize-fits-all model that is characteristic of Labor and does not optimally serve the provision of better health care in the community. On some occasions, hospital co-located afterhours clinics will be an appropriate solution, but often community needs can be better met by different solutions: clinics in the commuat nity, perhaps located close to public hospitals; private hospitals themselves; or dediconsulta- cated freestanding practices. The bill also rectifies a drafting error in the initial legislation that established the safety net. Australians incur a range of costs for medical services that extend beyond a GP visit: specialist consultations, pathology and outan ever-increasing array of radiology tests. Anyone who has experienced the costs associated with a serious accident or a complex long-term illness will know only too well how medical costs can quickly accumulate. enThe safety net is another example of the government acting speedily to provide assistance for Australians in these circumstances. This bill ensures that eligibility for the safety net at the $300 threshold will be confirmed for all families that are eligible for family tax benefit part A payments. A drafting error in the original bill meant that families who deferred their family tax benefit payments might have missed out on safety net eligibility at the lower threshold. This confirms their eligibility and gives the minister the power to determine that a registered family is an FTB A family for the purpose of the safety net $300 medical out-of-pocket cost threshold. As I said at the outset of my speech, after some vicissitudes in its attitudes towards Medicare the coalition has demonstrated an unequivocal commitment to Medicare and to ensuring that all Australians have improved access to affordable medical services. Strengthening Medicare and Round the Clock Medicare were important parts of that process; so too is the subject of the bill now before the House-100 per cent Medicare. The government can be rightly proud of its achievements across a broad spectrum of policies and programs, and health is one of these. This bill continues the government's commitment to providing all Australians with better access to, and more affordable, medical services. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I rise to speak on the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004. During the recent election campaign, the Leader of the Opposition made it very clear that the 9 October election was going to be a referendum on Medicare. I would have to say that, when the people voted, they were fully aware that it is, in fact, the coalition that is one of the greatest supporters of Medicare. They recognised the fact that it is the coalition that has done so much to ensure the affordability of and access to medical services for Australians. And they were sure that it was the Liberal-National coalition that was going to keep the economy strong so that this government could spend the necessary funds to provide appropriate medical services for the people of Australia. This government has always been focused bill on providing the very best services under Medicare. The Medicare Plus program provided for some $2.4 billion to be invested in ensuring the very best in medical care for Australians. The government provided measures such as the $7.50 payment in my electorate to provide an incentive for GPs to bulk-bill children under the age of 16 and health care card holders. Under Medicare Plus there was additional support for practice nurses to ensure that our GPs get the support they need to provide the very best in medical services. There were additional places to train more GPs. More graduate doctors were being funded. This government has been totally focused on ensuring that the medical service needs of this country are adequately met. We also introduced the comprehensive Medicare safety net to ensure that the government bore a substantial proportion of people's health costs once their expenditure reached a certain threshold. I will talk a little more on that later. This government has also provided for the rural health initiative, providing substantial investment-some $562 million in the 2000 budget-to ensure that people in regional and rural areas had adequate access to health care services and to ensure that our GPs working in those isolated areas were adequately supported so that they could provide the services that people need. In my electorate, we have a branch of the rural clinical school, a highly successful initiative aimed at training doctors in regional and rural areas on the basis that, when they conclude their training, they are more likely to stay in those regional and rural areas. I have talked to some of the students and they have certainly indicated their intention that, when their training is done, they would like to practise in those areas. This government is highly aware that the shortage of GPs and the work force issues are major impediments to providing services in our more isolated areas and in regional areas. What was Labor's response to the health care needs of this nation? Quite remarkably, they came up with an unaffordable concept called Medicare Gold-offering a pot of gold at the end of the health care rainbow. On 9 October, the people totally rejected Medicare Gold. The people of Australia knew that it could not be provided. The people of Australia knew that the services as promised would not be delivered. The people of Australia knew that, for the provision of health care, it was inappropriate to discriminate purely on the basis of chronological age. I am pleased to see that the people of Australia supported this government on 9 October and supported the fact that this government supports Medicare. Part of the package that this government put forward is the subject of this bill we are debating today-increasing the Medicare rebate from 85 per cent to 100 per cent of the schedule fee for GP services. Through this measure, the government is investing more than $1.7 billion over four years to make GP services more affordable for all Australians. The passage of this bill will be a real test the opposition. They have been very much a party of obstruction, a party keen to work not towards the best interests of Australia but towards obstructing those measures which this government wants to put forward for the improvement of this country. Under this bill patients will benefit substantially. They will benefit substantially because the fees payable to a GP will rise from $26.25 to $30.85-an increase of some $4.60. But this measure does not just benefit those patients who are attending a doctor who bulk-bills. Through a higher rebate, the legislation provides an increased incentive for doctors to bulk-bill but, for those doctors who do not bulk-bill, the patient will be required to pay a smaller gap because the amount reimbursed by the government is increased. The second measure under this bill relates to eligibility for the Medicare safety net. The extended Medicare safety net covers 80 per cent of out-of-pocket costs for medical services provided outside hospital once the annual threshold is met. The government wants to ensure that all families who are eligible for FTB part A are eligible for the extended safety net at the lower $300 threshold. This amendment will allow FTB A family groups, such as families who elect to defer all of their FTB A fortnightly instalment payments or families who do not receive any FTB A because of an obligation to repay a debt to the Commonwealth, to fall within the definition of the FTB A family for the purposes of the safety net. This amendment will allow the Minister for Health and Ageing to determine that additional families such as these are FTB A families who are eligible for the lower safety net threshold even though they are not in receipt of an instalment or lump sum payment. The Minister for Health and Ageing is abfor solutely committed to Medicare. He has worked very hard to address the issues of work force shortage. He has worked very hard to ensure that Medicare is meeting the needs of Australians. In contrast, Labor put forward Medicare Gold-a strategy that was undeliverable and unaffordable. It was pie in the sky. Labor, as I said, wanted to discriminate against patients who were under a particular chronological age. Labor's strategies were focused on bulk-billing doctors; therefore they discriminated against those patients who attended surgeries where there was no bulk-billing, where the doctors chose not to bulk-bill particular patients. It was of great concern to me when, in the election campaign, the Leader of the Opposition admitted that he did not believe in a safety net; that Labor did not believe in a safety net; that Labor did not believe that those who were the sickest in the community, those who were the most needy because they had the highest levels of medical expenditure, were entitled to the protection that this safety provided. During the election campaign I was walking through a shopping centre at Toormina Gardens and an elderly couple came up to me. They were absolutely terrified that the opposition was going to take away the safety net. They were a couple who were not enjoying the best of health. They were a couple who were on a limited income and they were depending on the Medicare safety net to ensure their access to medical services and to ensure that they were able to afford the necessary out-of-pocket expenses that would be incurred due to the fact that they were both quite ill. The words of the opposition leader were absolutely frightening them. It is of great concern to me that many people in my electorate were very worried by the prospect that the safety net would be taken away. In fact, in the electorate of Cowper, some 5,000 people benefited from the Medicare safety net-5,000 people who would have had their benefits rejected if, on 9 October, the people of Australia had elected a Labor government. As I have said before, this government has been absolutely focused on the need to strengthen Medicare. The Labor Party have been focused on the fact that they do not support a safety net and that they do not support the very good measures that this government has introduced. This government is focused on the fact that the bulk-billing statistic is not the be-all and end-all of proper medical services. A particular number, the bulk-billing percentage, is not the measure of affordability of and access to medical services around the country. The bulk-billing percentage is not a measure of whether people in isolated areas have access to appropriate medical services. This government has put in place the sorts of measures that have strengthened Medicare. This government has put in place the sorts of measures that have provided imnet proved medical outcomes for people in isolated areas, in regional areas and in rural areas. This government has given GPs the support they need to provide the medical services for those people. This government has given GPs an added incentive to bulk-bill, as I have said, children under the age of 16 and health care card holders. This government has proven to be a friend of Medicare. The people of Australia recognised that on 9 October. I commend this bill to the House. NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 9.00 p.m., I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. Communications: Media Ownership

Speaker: Mr MURPHY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Lowe) (9.00 p.m.)Honourable members will be well aware of my long standing campaign in this House concerning the Howard government's agenda to further concentrate the ownership of traditional media in Australia, and the serious implications this holds for the public interest and for our precious democracy. We need to remain vigilant on this issue, particularly as the government will soon be able to ram through the Senate legislation that will water down one of the few remaining checks against further concentration of media ownership in Australia. Having just two major newspaper companies in our country is bad enough. If honourable members want an example of how this lowers standards, I refer them to two recent editions of the Australian newspaper. Last Saturday the paper carried a story by Christine Jackman and Cameron Stewart, entitled ‘Losing it', which purported to be a ‘definitive account' of how Mark Latham lost the 2004 federal election. It opened with a claim that during the federal election the Leader the Opposition cancelled a barbecue for families that was planned for the seat of ParJackman. ramatta and went elsewhere that day to make an announcement. The first point I make to the House tonight is that this claim is false. Further, I have spoken with a number of people from my electorate who attended the barbecue and who spoke with Mr Latham. Today's edition of the Australian carries letter of response from Mr Latham's office. This letter also proves the claim to be wrong on at least seven grounds: (1) the Leader of the Opposition attended the function as planned; (2) he was greeted by more than 200 guests; (3) he spoke to the crowd for more than 15 minutes about Labor's plan to ease the squeeze on families; (4) the Leader of the Opposition made his announcement there, and not elsewhere as claimed in the story; (5) more than 20 journalists attended the function; (6) radio news bulletins that day, and television news bulletins that night, carried coverage of Mr Latham being there; and (7) the Sun-Herald carried a report on the following day that said the announcement was ‘unveiled at a community barbecue at Wentworthville in the marginal Coalitionheld seat of Parramatta'. In other words, a simple check of the lic record would have prevented the mistake made by the journalists involved in last Saturday's article. And yet, operating in complete denial, the Australian today carries an editor's note still insisting that Mr Latham ditched the plan and failed to participate as scheduled. When a newspaper, presented with clear and publicly available evidence, cannot acknowledge that it has made a mistake, it demonstrates arrogance and a cavalier attitude to the need to uphold the basic standards of journalism. An even more remarkable demonstration of the quality of journalism involved in last Saturday's article is the fact that the Australian's editor-inof chief contacted at least one person-that I am aware of-asking them to speak with Ms So I ask the House tonight: do editors now act as booking agents? If Ms Jackman cannot secure interviews on her own, and produces slaphappy journalism that is riddled with errors and light on facts, how does she hold down her job? What on earth is going on at a the Australian? One thing is certain: further concentration of media ownership will not help. Australians deserve to have a wider choice and broader competition. That is in the public interest, and it is good for our democracy. Aviation: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport

Speaker: Mrs HULL
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: It is good news week, and today is good news day for me. Tonight I have much pleasure in indicating to the House that we have finally resolved the issue of Regional Express airlines and the problem of their relocation from gate 39 at terminal 2 of Sydney airport. What we have today is a great agreement and a wonderful outcome for a running issue we have all been very concerned about. We have a new Regional Express gate lounge, we have a new Regional Express lounge facility, pub- and Regional Express will stay at gate 39 until the building improvements are completed at their new lounge at gate 47. The chairman of Regional Express, Lim Kim Hi, and the co-chairman, Lee Thian Soo, welcome this great news, because it has been an issue for their airline. I congratulate Max Moore-Wilton, Rod Gilmour and the entire team at Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd for their cooperation with Regional Express for the benefit of rural communities. My good friend Geoff Bruest, Jim Davis and the great team at Regional Express have worked tirelessly on this issue to ensure that regional commuters are able to get access to quality facilities that will ensure that the gateway to rural and regional New South Wales and other areas can be upheld and sustained. I would again like to give my enormous personal thanks to John Anderson's office. They have been magnificent in their commitment to a successful resolution for Regional Express. Again and again, the Deputy Prime Minister; his chief of staff, Peter Langhorne; and his aviation adviser, Peter Marchi, rallied to ensure that regional commuters and Regional Express airlines would be provided with facilities that are befitting this growing and successful airline. Mr Speaker, you will recall only too well that it was only two years ago that you and I had many conversations on the demise of Ansett and the demise of Kendall Airlines, which had been running in and out of our electorates. We had no airline operating right throughout regional areas. In fact, many of our areas would have had a very dire future had it not been for the commitment of the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, to ensuring that we would access regional services. As a consequence, we had an enormous amount of trial and effort but everyone stayed true to the few airlines that were combined to ultimately get Regional Express into the skies. I must at this time pay tribute again to one of the former operators in Regional Express, Michael Jones, who had the tenacity, the integrity and I guess the belligerence to ensure that this airline got up and running and offering services. I would like to congratulate the board of Regional Express for their commitment to ensuring that regional commuters have the quality, varied and continuing service that they provide. They have certainly proven themselves. They have now moved into profit after only two years of operation. Their profits are extending into the millions of dollars now and their passenger numbers are extending into the millions as well. I am very proud of this airline. This airline is based in Wagga Wagga. It employs about 120 people in Wagga Wagga. It makes a large contribution to the entire community and to the entire electorate. It is with great pleasure and relief that I congratulate Sydney Airport Corporation, Regional Express and the Deputy Prime Minister's office for again showing true commitment to ensuring that Australians in rural and regional New South Wales have facilities that are second to none and to ensuring that they are guaranteed a service which they can be proud of and which can continue to grow into the future. Mr Speaker, thank you for allowing me the opportunity to give these congratulations in the House on the evening of a very successful negotiation between this airline, Sydney Airport Corporation and the Deputy Prime Minister's office. Electorate of Blaxland: Donovan, Ms Casey

Speaker: Mr HATTON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Blaxland) (9.09 p.m.)Touchdown! It is a touchdown for the Speaker because he has been elected to an august office in this House. He is a person who has served the parliament for a long period of time and someone who has been selected by his peers to fill a significant place within this parliament. It is a touchdown for a person who yesterday gave his first speech in this House, the member for Wentworth, Malcolm Turnbull. I congratulated him at the end of that speech-a significant one, I thought. The only regret I have is that he is not on our side of the House rather than the coalition side. His story is the story of a lot of Australians: ple who started with virtually nothing, who worked very hard and used their abilities and talents to achieve as much as was possible for them. I salute him for what he has achieved personally in that regard and for the fact that he has chosen to use his abilities his talents in this parliament. I simply regret that he is not one of ours but one of theirs. Mr Speaker, we have been friends since I came into this parliament in 1996. My knowledge of you was increased when you led a delegation of parliamentarians from both sides of the House to South America. I deeply appreciate the way in which you led that delegation. It was indicative of the fact that you will be able to operate as Speaker of this House in a bipartisan way, which will add to the reputation of the House but also to the way in which the House operates. But it is a touchdown not only for the member for Wannon and for the member for Wentworth but, more importantly for me as the member for Bankstown, this is a touchdown for Casey Donovan, Australian idol. Bankstown properly should be renamed Caseytown as a result of what happened very recently. Mr Ripoll-Shameless.

Speaker: Mr HATTON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: It is entirely shameless but entirely right. Casey Donovan is a 16year-old kid. It is a long time ago but I can remember what it was like to be 16. I can remember what it was like to be pilloried throughout most of my life because I was not the Australian average in terms of size. I can remember what it was like to be different. I can remember what it was like to not completely fit in. But I can also remember what it was like to, despite all of that, win the acceptance of my peers in a leadership position. For me, the first instance was as captain of De La Salle College Bankstown at the age of 16. I can remember what it was like to be peotrusted over people who were more gifted in other areas-athletic ones and so on. They put a kid in that people would not normally have thought of. But what Casey Donovan has done, as a young person of 16 years of age-a person and mature beyond those 16 years-under incredible pressure but using her native talent, has been to show not just Bankstown but the world as well that talent can win through. She has shown that if you accept what you have and what you have been given and you develop that and you school it and, in the best instances of education, you bring it out of yourself and you do not have a fear of simply being yourself and expressing thatas the members for Wannon and Wentworth, and others, have done in this place-you can conquer and you can do well. Very few of the people who initially looked at it realised what an absolute phenomenon the Australian Idol program would become. I knew from the last time, when Paulini-who was also from Bankstowncame in fourth, that this was a significant social phenomenon in Australia. But I also knew that in Bankstown, Bankstown City Council, together with the state education department, put money and effort and time into TAP, the Talent Advancement Program, for all of those children in public schools in Bankstown who were willing to try to tap the best of their abilities. First time up in a national competition, Paulini came fourth. Second time up, against all of the odds, Casey Donovan beat someone who was extremely gifted, the young Mr Callea from Melbourne and the electorate of Lalor. For someone who established their naturalness and humanity, who simply expressed themselves as fully as possible and who allied that to a brilliant singing talent, Bankstown should be renamed Caseytown. For Casey Donovan and for Bankstown it is an absolute touchdown that she was able to touch the lives and the hearts of people across Australia. (Time expired) Regional Services: Program Funding

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I understand that today Tamworth businessman Mr Greg Maguire released a statement in which he categorically rejected as untrue further statements made yesterday by Independent New England MP Tony Windsor under parliamentary privilege in relation to an alleged phone call between Mr Maguire and Mr Windsor, supposedly concerning the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson. The statement went on: In parliament, Mr Windsor alleged that Mr Maguire told him in a phone call a few days 20 September 2004 that the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr John Anderson, had made a phone call to Mr Maguire. Mr Windsor alleged that the message conveyed in that call was, “Get your mate to pull back; this is bigger than all of us.” Mr Maguire had no phone call with Mr Windsor in which he made any such statement as now alleged by Mr Windsor concerning the deputy prime minister, Mr Anderson … Further, neither in September 2004, nor at any time, did Mr Anderson convey any such message as is now alleged by Mr Windsor to Mr Maguire. Mr Maguire also said that at no stage did Mr Anderson or anyone else on behalf of the government convey to Mr Maguire that funding for the Australian Equine and Livestock Centre was subject to or dependent on political strings or any other appropriate conditions. On the contrary, Mr Anderson made it abundantly clear that the funding for the centre at the federal level was dependent on the project being supported on its merits. The New South Wales state government approach on this matter was the same. I am concerned that recently we have seen the member for New England using parliamentary privilege not to promote the interests of the electorate of order. I think the honourable member for Cowper may be adversely reflecting on a member of this House. There are forms of the House in which he can prosecute such statements. Mr Andrews- Mr Speaker, contrary to the position put by the Chief Opposition Whip, so far in my observation and hearing the member for Cowper has done no such thing.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I call the member for Cowper, and I am sure he is mindful of the standing orders.

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Thank you, Mr after Speaker. My concern is that perhaps parliamentary privilege is being used not to advance the interests of the electorate, not to advance the interests of the constituents, but for personal purposes. This to me is of great concern. I think in this House all members, despite our political differences of order. Clearly, the honourable member for Cowper wants to suggest that the actions of the honourable member for New England were motivated by personal reasons, not out of concern for his electorate or the needs of his electorate. If that is his belief, there are forms of the House which he can use to prosecute such an argument, but the adjournment is not one of them.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I have been listening carefully to the remarks. I rule that the member is in order.

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I think that all of us as members of this House need to cultivate those relationships that will best benefit our constituents, and it is my concern that recent statements have not achieved that end-they have not advanced the interests of the people of New England. Today we had a number of questions on this issue, and one was about an invitation. Rather than using question time to obtain more information about issues relating to the equine centre and the furthering of that project, questions were raised about whether a particular individual was invited to a particular function. One would have to ask whether those types of questions, in the very valuable forum that is question time, are in the best interests of our country and the best interests of the people within the electorate of the member concerned. I ask: as members of parliament, how are we best placed to further the interests of our electorate? I believe it by working cooperatively, using the forum of this House to work together and achieve real outcomes for our constituents. As members we should, despite our political differences, always be working- (Time expired) Eureka Stockade: 150th Anniversary Williams, Mr Alan ‘Beau'

Speaker: Ms KING
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: This being my first opportunity to speak in the House, can I congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on your elevation to the chair. Sharing an electorate boundary with you and also having represented part of your seat previously, I am sure that the people of Stawell, Avoca and the towns of Glenorchy, Marnoo, Navarre and fabulous Waubra will be justifiably proud of you. The subject of my adjournment speech tonight will be of little surprise to members of this House. This week marks the 150th anniversary of the Eureka Stockade. In 1854, anyone wishing to mine on the goldfields in Victoria was required to pay a licence fee every three months. Many miners queued up in the early days to pay the fee, expecting improvements to roads and health and education facilities. These improvements were not forthcoming. The licence fee was considered by many as unfair, as it fell upon everyone regardless of their ability to pay or the amount of gold they did or did not find. The issue of taxation without the basic democratic right of representation led to a number of meetings of miners, where concerns were expressed about licence fees and the policing of the licence fees. The most significant of these meetings was the meeting of the Ballarat Reform League on 11 November and the ‘monster meeting' at Bakery Hill on 29 November 1854, where over a third of the Ballarat population gathered. The Ballarat Reform League had as part of their demands full and fair representais tion, manhood suffrage, no property qualifications for members of the legislative council, payment of members and short duration of parliament-things we take for granted as part of our democracy today. The diggers then marched from Bakery Hill to the area chosen to establish the Eureka Stockade. Tensions came to a head in a pre-dawn raid on 3 December 1854, with police and soldiers joining forces. At least 16 nations were represented at Eureka, with 28 people dying and a number of others unaccounted for. A century ago, Mark Twain visited Australia and said of Eureka: It was a revolution-small in size; but great politically; it was a strike for liberty, a struggle for a principle, a stand against injustice and oppression. It was the Barons and John, over again; it was Hampden and Ship-Money; it was Concord and Lexington; small beginnings, all of them, but all of them great in political results, all of them epoch-making. It is another instance of a victory won by a lost battle. Eureka is not owned by any one political party or political cause. I am an avid student of history and its importance, and as the member for Ballarat I proudly highlight Eureka-and would do so regardless of which political party I was from. Eureka is a great national story that deserves greater national recognition. I was encouraged to see the leader of the Victorian opposition, Robert Doyle, in Ballarat alongside the Leader of the Victorian Nationals and the Premier of Victoria last Friday. The Leader of the Opposition and I were the only representatives of the federal parliament, as the Prime Minster had declined an invitation and sent no representative. In today's Age, Gerard Henderson has written a terrific piece that argues there is a tradition in the Liberal Party supportive of the Eureka legend that deserves a hearing. He argues convincingly that the Liberal Party is missing the point of the Eureka commemorations and should be proud to claim this national story as part of the Liberal tion, just as Labor does. I live in hope. Ballarat has put on a magnificent display this week, with events continuing until Sunday. I want to congratulate all involved. I could not have been prouder of the way in which the event is being commemorated by the local Ballarat community. In the few remaining minutes I would like to take the opportunity to note the passing this morning of Alan ‘Beau' Williams at the age of 93. Beau was a great stalwart of the Ballarat labour movement. He was a boilermaker by trade, who as a teenager commenced his apprenticeship at the Ballarat railways and worked there for over 20 years. Beau earned his nickname from the hat he used to wear while splitting wood in the Enfield forest with his friends. I am told the hat resembled the hat worn in the then popular newly released film Beau Jess. He earned the nickname in his 40s and it stuck for life. Beau served as Secretary of the Ballarat Trades and Labour Council from 1956 to 1975, a time of enormous tension within Victoria and certainly in Ballarat, at the heart of the split between the ALP and the DLP. He presided over many heated debates, splitting the chamber between the Left and the Right at the Ballarat Trades and Labour Council. The debates were particularly heated over the issue of conscription. Beau stood as a federal Labor candidate in the 1960s. I was proud to present Beau with a Centenary Medal in 2002. He was tireless in his efforts to represent working people in my district. Ballarat is a better place for you having been with us. Vale Beau Williams. Frost, Dame Phyllis

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Menzies-Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service) (9.24 p.m.)-I would like to commend to the House the memory of a tradigreat Australian, Dame Phyllis Frost, who died recently. Dame Phyllis was one of the few people in our community who became famous for the best of reasons: for taking the role of a professional beggar for thankless causes, most notably the plight of women prisoners in Victoria. Born into a Croydon family in 1917, Dame Phyllis lived in that community all her life. Her Presbyterian parents instilled in her and her sisters the ethos of charity to the less well off. During the Depression her parents helped to feed and clothe, in their front parlour, those unfortunately devastated from their local township. Phyllis Frost became involved in prison reform when an acquaintance was incarcerated for a minor crime in the 1940s. Shocked into action by the degrading conditions that prisoners have endured since the 19th century, she lobbied to change and improve policies towards women prisoners. She studied criminology and, in 1953, she established the Victorian Women's Prisons Council, for many years assisting women as they served sentences. She served as the chair of this organisation for some 46 years. Phyllis Frost was also involved in around 47 mainly charitable committees and organisations, and helped raise millions of dollars for charity. In 2000 the Victorian government honoured her achievements with women prisoners by renaming the Deer Park Metropolitan Women's Correctional Centre to the Dame Phyllis Frost Centre. The centre, with its humanising design, was the apex of her policy drive and is a model for other states. Survived by her three daughters, five grandchildren and three great-grandsons, Dame Phyllis Frost was tireless, obstinate, frank, mischievous and a real achiever with real legacies. She was, in short, a great Australian. Many here would remember her daughter, Pauline Osmond, who served previous Speakers of the House of Representatives with great professionalism. Our thoughts are especially with her daughter, Pauline, tonight. Question agreed to. House adjourned at 9.27 p.m. NA The following notices were given: Mr Abbott to present a bill for an act to amend legislation relating to private health insurance, and for related purposes. (National Health Amendment (Prostheses) Bill 2004) Mr Abbott to move: That the Clerk be authorised to correct clerical errors or inconsistencies in wording in the standing orders, but not so as to cause a change to the meaning of any standing order. Dr Stone to present a bill for an act to amend Commonwealth financial management legislation and other financial and reporting provisions, and for related purposes. (Financial Framework Legislation Amendment Bill 2004) Mr Hunt to present a bill for an act to provide for water efficiency labelling and the making of water efficiency standards, and for related purposes. (Water Efficiency Labelling and Standards Bill 2004) Mr Lloyd to move: That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the House approves the following proposal for works in the Parliamentary Zone which was presented to the House on 30 November 2004 namely: Replacement and extension of cooling towers at Old Parliament House. Mr Baird to move: That this House: (1) notes with concern; (a) the ongoing humanitarian and human rights crisis in the Darfur region of Western Sudan; and (b) the decimation of this area and the south of the country by Janjaweed and the ongoing civil war; (2) commends the Government for its: (a) recent commitment to provide a further $12 million in aid to the region in addition to the $8 million committed in May and June of this year; and (b) continued support for the establishment of a United Nations intervention in the area to ensure the delivery of aid; and (3) urges the United Nations to emphasise to the al-Bashir Government the importance of intervention to the safety of Darfuris and the provision of assistance throughout the country.
